number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
8, 2014
												Do you like pirates? Yes? Well then we have the game for ye matey!General: Sid Meier's Pirates!(I will refer to it as SMP! from now on) is a... pirate RPG... I guess? You take command of a young pirate and sail through the Caribbean in a strategy-ish POV. Your goal is to rescue your family from the clutches of gang of evil spanish dudes without dying. Now dear reader you will say well of course you shouldn't die that is quite obvious. Well it is not, in SMP! you only have a limited time to plunder until you are too old for the sea. That means be quick and find as many unique items that will prolong your life as possible.Visuals: SMP! looks due to it's sunny style and perspective quite good even for todays standarts.Audio: The sounds are not always synced with what is happening but are not bad enough for you to generally notice.Open World: The World feels incredibly alive as the differnet nations go to war, cities change their owner and missions are not as static as in other games.Gameplay: In SMP! you there are 2 kinds of missions, the ones that are directly tied to the story and side missions. Both however sometimes randomly collide as the Baron that kidnapped your family has also kidnapped your fiance.  Long story short: everything that you see in the world is something you "can do" and all of those activities are worth it, the Seas have tough spots and it all feels very alive. (Almost) Nothing that has to be triggered the old-fashioned way in a wacky sunny-pirate setting that reminds me of movies like "Mutiny on the Bounty".Story: While in itself the game offers a decent revenge story, the way the missions work make the game drag on.Basicly you hunt down those corrupt spanish guys to get information on the location of your family members(that look just like the day you lost them). However you will have to repeat this hunt multiple times to get to one of your family members. This is probably the only major problem the game has and even that is not that bad since there is more to do besides the Story missions.Final Verdict: Alive happy-go lucky Pirate awesomeness. SMP! is one of my favorite games and I can only recommend buying it especially if you like Pirates.~Captain AndGeo

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2015
												Please bear in mind, the following is my opinion alone. You may disagree with my opinion.Sid Meier's Pirates! is an old game, but still a good one.For starters, the map is huge. There are many, many settlements which means many, many ships. More ships means more conflict, which makes for a more fun game.The duelling system is good, however after about 10 duels or so it becomes mind-numbingly repetitive, and you just end up choosing the rapier and mashing 4 all the time.I like how there is no "best" ship - sure, the massive ships have a huge hull capacity and they can therefore carry more guns and more crew, but the massive ships are very slow whereas the smaller ships which have a smaller hull capacity and have less cannons are much faster and they can dodge their way out of ramming and situations with superior ships. They can even dodge cannonballs.Because logic.The graphics aren't very good, but give the devs a break, it was made in 2004.There are some cons, like with every game. There is a bug where when you go back onto your ship (when you have gone onto land) with the spyglass still in use, your ship moves ridiculously slowly and the spyglass is still there, meaning you have to go through the incredibly tedious process of turning around at 0.000000001 knots and landing again, then putting away the spyglass and getting back on the ship.And there is very little variation in the gameplay so after one or two playthroughs it becomes extraordinarily boring.However, while it still lasts, this game is worth buying. It's bad, but it's also very good.RATINGSGraphics - 4/10Gameplay - 6.5/10Story Originality - 1/10The Actual Story - 2/10Value for Money - 5/10Replayability - 4/10Length - Can't be rated, there isn't a definite point where the game ends, but you get bored after about 10 hours (counts as 6/10)Extra Special Feature - Balanced ships and huge mapMy Final Rating:6.8/10GoodMean Average rounded to 3 dp:4.071/10

content:
ry 12, 2014
												Game of the year, every year. This game was fantastic upon it's rerelease in 2005, and it has yet to be matched. The quintessential pirate game, with the bare minimum of missing features and an exceptional amount of depth.Want to sail around and plunder Spanish Treasure ships? Sure.Want to find take down the 9 most notorious pirates in the Carib? Go for it.Want to find treasure map fragments and search around distant jungles to find them? There are hundreds.Strategy Minigame? Check. Stealth Minigame? Check. Dancing Minigame? You bet your ♥♥♥. Duelling mingame? Naturally.This game has everything, all fine tuned and polished, not a single bug to be found. The style is timeless, casual and silly but not lacking. If you thought that AC:Black Flag had a good pirate thing going, then you need to pick this up and be blown away.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
8, 2014
												8/10For however long I have been playing this game, I can give a few things that I think would be helpful to someone debating on buying this. I bought this for like $2.50 when a sale was going on. The game is DEFINITLY worth at least $10.00 though...Goods:-Open world partly on ship, very little on land, some forced minigame, easy UI for movement.-Fun missions.-You get the sense of accomplishment for doing practically anything but losing.-Treasure maps are an entertaining game dynamic.-Take over literally ANY ship and use it as your own.-Raiding towns is fun.-Player items actually make a difference in a variety of aspects of the game.Neutrals:-Gameplay dynamics and reward increments revolve around difficulty.-Dancing can get more difficult as difficulties progress, and having to press 1 of 8 options in the fraction of a second based off of your partner's gestures is not very simple.-Crew is hard to keep happy unless all you do is what pirates would do even though the game gives you the ability to be 'good'.-Graphics match their time.-Winds heavily effect movement around the map.-You only retain your flagship when you give the crew members their cut.-Some ships will not engage in ship to ship warfare and instead will follow windward right into you and force you into a cinematic minigame.-Only about 6-8 ship upgrades.Bads:-Sometimes can be very repetitive.-Sailing down certain inlets can cause the game to continually ask you if you would like to anchor.-The Spanish own the entire south half of the Caribbean. (Not really as bad since it is pretty historically accurate. more difficult attacking vessels without upsetting the Spanish).-When escorting another ship, another WILL spawn and attack you at some point on the voyage.

content:
8, 2014
												I got hooked on the Sid Meier's Pirates! series years ago and I was glad I was able to find this version on PC.Aesthetically the game isn't what most people are used to seeing these days but it is an older game and is very detailed in it's artwork. The period-centric music and sounds are great and while there is no actual dialouge, the gibberish word-sounding noises characters make can be hillarious in the right scenarios. The mechanics on the PC version work a little different so if you're used to the XBOX version like I was be prepared to retrain your and when you start dancing with the governer's daughter.It is a pirate game so you have plenty of booty and plunder to acquire as well as hidden treasures and lost cities and both sea battles and sword fight. Aside from the standard fighting and looting you find in most pirate games, Pirates! offers up trade goods to sell, daughters to be wooed and married to, and more importantly keeping your crew's morale high so you can stay at sea longer.

												The first time I heard or played this game was when my friend let me borrow his copy for the PSP, and I loved it. Naturally, I jumped at the opportunity to own the PC edition. Along with Assassin's Creed IV, this is one of the few games out there that simulate the life of an 18th century pirate in an open-world Caribbean Sea. Though the graphics are dated and the storyline is weak (this is a Sid Meyer game, what do you expect?), the game's distinctive charm makes every boarding/treasure hunt/etc. exciting, and the swath of hidden features to find (romance, turn-based strategy, and so on) will keep you up for hours.

content:
ry 22, 2014
												9/10This game is one of my favourite Sandbox Games that i've played in the last 2 years. Your family is imprisoned by an evil Spaniard, the Marquis Montalban! By this time, you are a young boy, who manages to escape imprisonment. 18 years later, you are a fully grown man, who decides to sign up on a ship (of your choosing). You decide whether to join crew with the Spanish, the Dutch, the French, or the English. Either way, you later mutiny against your captain with nearly the rest of the crew. After defeating the captain, the crew elects you captain. You are then allowed to do whatever you wish. Be that fighting for a certain nationality, being a Pirate and attacking everything in sight, raiding towns, attacking merchant ships, trying to rescue your long lost family, defeating the 9 best pirates in the game (Blackbeard, Henry Morgan, Stede Bonnet ETC) or just doing whatever you feel like doing.The game may take a bit of time to get adjusted to, but in the end, the amount of enjoyment and fun you recieve from playing this is just amasing! So overal, I HIGHLY recommend getting this game, especially when its on special sale thing (like the Steam Summer Sale ETC).

content:
20, 2016
												I was actually extremely surprised by how good this game was. I picked it up during a weekend sale based on reviews by some of the other steam users. I couldn't believe that so many people enjoyed a game that's essentially for kids.Sid Meier's Pirates! puts you in the role of a buccaneer who had his family kidnapped by your traditional "evil noble". You sign up with one of four major empires--England, France, Spain or Norway--and sink ships, conquer cities, raid caravans and fight off rogue pirates. As a naval leader, you rise in rank from a simple privateer all the way up to the commander of the royal navy. You outfit all of the ships in your fleet and engage in sea battles for ultimate supremacy of the Caribbeans.Sid Meier's Pirates has a surprising amount of depth for such a simplistic game. It has political elements, economics, resource management, sword duelling and...dancing. Yes. There is ballroom dancing in Sid Meier's Pirates. Let that sink in for a moment.I think it has something to offer for everyone. However, there are some downfalls. The difficulty quickly dies down as you amass larger, more well-armed ships. The various game aspects become repetitive after the 8 or 9 hour mark, and the campaign--which is quite short--can be completed with almost no difficulty, especially after acquiring the Duke's ship. There is a lot to do, but it can be done in a short amount of time. I finished the game and most of the quests in about 3.5 hours. So, while it is a good game, it doesn't exceed its financial value in any way. You get what you pay for, plus a little extra.PROS++ Expansive map with a lot to do.++ Amazing ship battles; very engaging and fun!++ Many different activities and side quests to complete apart from the campaign.++ SWORD DUELLING! CONS-- Limited story elements.-- Main campaign is shallow and easy to complete.-- Not much replayability once the quests are done.-- The ballroom dancing. Blech. As a guy, that was cringeworthy.Overall, the game is worth about a 7.5/10. Definitely a good game and worth the money.

content:
28, 2016
												Sid Meier's Pirates is not only an interesting exploration into the world of necromancy but also an engaging PSA about recycling.The game is continuously stuck in some sort of tutorial mode from the first to third difficulty where it punishes you for trying to make the game harder by stealing all of your gold. As soon as you hit Swashbuckler however the game becomes a torment where everything from wind, your crew and even your family hates your guts and wishes to destroy you.The final difficulty however isn't even mentioned by most players who can give you hundreds of strategies for Swashbuckler but not a single for Rogue. It really is just better to forget that this difficulty even exists. It will test your limits as it rips every shred of humanity from you until you're either begging for mercy or some kind of robotic killing machine of the colonial seas. No matter how good you are on Rogue the swordfight with the final boss in his fortress has been designed as a testing protocol for T-800 units instead of being a game for actual human beings to complete.Oh and good luck with the dancing minigame.

content:
, 2011
												Pirates! is a really classic game for me - though I admit it could be part of its appeal to me was that it was so far ahead of its time when it came out. Free roaming, sailing with different handling depending on the size of the ship, a map based on the real world, two types of battle, leadership, piracy and privateering for political gain, marrying women, hunting treasure, searching for long-long relatives and trying to quell your crew from mutiny... all in a game from the mid-1980s. The only thing that even nearly matched it in terms of depth was Elite.It's received updates, and updates, and updates, and... it's still the same game, at the core.

content:
1, 2014
												I brought my thirst and swag into a local tavern off an island I was sailing by, we proceeded to drink and dice, and having a luck roll of 77 when I was born, the gambling addict was soon out of money. He proceeded to bring me into a back room and show me this girl he had found as a stow away. Double or nothing he says for the girl as collateral, Wanting to bang out as many chicks as possible before the redcoats end my reign of terror I of course accept and walk away with a new wench. She proceeds to tell me she is looking for her husband, a naval officer who went missing, and If i was a decent man I'd help her. I proceeded to shut her down and make her train my sailors to bring morale up. A year goes by and I'm at another tavern; a man comes up to me and tells me that I own his wife and hes been looking for her all this time, would I part with her out of a sense of lost romance and love? I of course decline because this isnt a charity, he offers 10,000 gold, I accept. Its 4am and I log off, when I retern my coffers are filled with 1,000,000,000 Gold.  I proceeded to throw volley after volley of conscripted men into the meat grinder of local forts until I owned the worlds best fleet. Needless to say the game was ruined after that, but I was the best pirate in the land.

I'd recommend it if you like old school games, but if you aren't into playing remade old games then skip this one as you aren't going to get any real modern play mechanics.

												FIXED!: I still say "buyers beware", but I have found a reliable, and good fix for the problems I have been having. I am hoping this fix is good for anyone else who was having the same issue. It is a game made before Windows Vist, 7, and 8, and thus was not optimized for play on those versions. I hope these solutions work for you, so that you can seemlessly enjoy this classic.Fixes random crashes: http://www.pcgamer.com/2014/07/31/pixel-boost-sid-meiers-pirates/?ns_campaign=article-feed&ns_mchannel=ref&ns_source=steam&ns_linkname=0&ns_fee=0Fixes "steam not found" error: http://forums.steampowered.com/forums/showpost.php?p=26798077&postcount=13----------I love this game. I have spent hours and hours playing this before, on Xbox, as well as Windows. However, I cannot play this version for more than 15 minutes before it crashes. It is really annoying. There are some compatibility issues with modern versions of Windows that cause this, and has never been patched. I recomend this game if you are playing on a Windows XP machine. However, if you are on Vista or later, especially 64 bit, just beware.

content:
2016
												No other game stole so many hours of my childhood.  Well, maybe Rollercoaster Tycoon Gold, but that's besides the point!  This timeless open-world sand-- er, waterbox-- gives you a ship and wishes you well, then reels in the anchors to let you do whatever the hell you want.  Sure, you could be a hero and save your family from slavery at the hands of an evil and abusive Marquis, but... why would you?  There's only so much time in your simulated pirate life, time that could be used to board Spanish trade galleons, to sack cities, to find ancient Incan ruins, to deliver ultimatums, to conquer all in the name of the Dutch, to beat up drunk tavern regulars, to buy treasure maps and moustaches from Sid Meier in the back corner of the tavern, to marry sixteen governors' daughters through your ballroom dancing swagger, to do whatever the hell you want!YAR HAR DIDDLY DEE, BEING A PIRATE IS ALRIGHT TO BE, DO WHAT YOU WANT CAUSE A PIRATE IS FREE, YOU ARE A PIRATE!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
y 27, 2016
												I really had my reservations about this game. It looked a little dated, and not much content. I do like ships and pirates and trading and after I got the game in a humble bundle i decided id give it a go. This game is wonderful. You start out as an apprentice level sailor with the que's flashing during fights and dances so you dont fail. Then journeyman comes around and the que's are gone and you have to see the movement of the person your fighting or dancing with to have an idea of what your defence/dance move should be.At first i thought it was dumb that you could only battle one ship, but that ship you have direct control over and it would be difficult to control more, and relying on AI to fight with you brings in risks of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ decisions. Over all, this game is really worth it. i would have paid the 10 bucks in full if i knew what i was getting into

content:
9
												Looking for someone to tell me I'm wrong with the following statement.  This game is perfect . . . except for:1. Ship speed is everything for winning this game on the hardest setting, thus making all the dif ships you can get moot; expecially trying to sail around slowly with a whole fleet--something you'd never do trying to win the hardest dif.2. The game provides several avenues for making money, but just basic capture/sell is so much faster/effective than anything else; which also makes the rest moot.3. The sneak-in-to-town mini-game is way to high risk vs. reward, so again in a game you're trying to win, you'd never do this . . . unlase you "save-scum"Recap: the designers put in multiple paths to victory in this game (a must for any "good" game), but once you discover the "correct" path, it is so overwhelmingly the "correct" path that even if you force yourself to try something different all you can think is this is stupid and can do task X in 1/2 the time (time - the greatest commodity in the game) by doing it the "best" way.  Again, please someone tell me I'm wrong.

content:
y 31, 2015
												My wife and I love this game so much we decided to make a let's play - who knew a game this old could still keep us hooked after all these years?   I love this game, my wife loves it, my kids love it, even my father in law played for hundreds of ours.  It's appropriate - and fun- for all ages.The combat is simplified, easy and very satisfying - the story is simple and satisfying, the graphics are still beautiful and compare to many modern indie games out there.  Actually now that I think of it, this was one of the first non dungeon rogue like games to come out.  Every game is different and you never know where the seas will take you.Highly recommended and we'd love to connect with other Sid Meier's Pirates players out there!Here is my wife and I playing what we call a thirty minute pirate game

ry 21, 2014
												When I first picked this game up from the Sid Meier Humble Bundle I looked at it with nothing but a slight idea of what was to come.  To be honest I didn't expect much at first but after getting into the game after an hour or so, I was hooked.  The game is simple in nature yet complex to master, as are many of Sid Meier's games.  The pirates theme is masterfully directed and the story, while lacking, doesn't need to be there in the first place.  You create your own story.  Become the most vile Pirate to ever sail the seven seas or be a noble sailor for one of the nations colonizing the area.  Seek revenge solely on those who took your family or loot and plunder everywhere and everyone.  This game is a masterpiece in every sense of the word.  Though it may be a bit clunky and awkward at points, it adds to the charm of the game.  I can not reccomend this game enough to anyone with interest in the pirate theme or anyone looking for a fun adventure.

												Pirates! is the all the swashbuckling fun a person could want from a pirate-themed video game without being too restrictive. It lays out a basic backstory with optional follow-through, but otherwises allows the player to run wild in the 17th Century Caribbean. At times, however, the game can be a little too hands off in terms of direction (explanation of game and world mechanics and parts of the "storyline"). The controls can a little confusing at first, and I would really recommend a number pad if using a laptop but a mouse is a good alternative also (I've used both and found that while the mouse is more convenient a number pad makes the game much easier to play). Overall, this game is easy to get a hang of quickly and you'll have a fantastic time pirating your way across the high seas.

content:
er 26, 2014
												Score: 10/10Although Sid Meier's Pirates! is a very old game, it gives the player an unrivaled pirate experience. You are free to make your choices and shape the world in any way you see fit, and that is what I call a true RPG. Which brings us to what I believe is the strongest point of this game, the hability to provide an amazing interaction with the game world, even if you don't realized as you do, as every action brings a reaction somewhere. If you save the merchant ship from the pirates, your allies may prosper, but that very pirate ship that you sunk will be a hard hit in the pirate community. Or, if you are to become the most fiered pirate of the seas, you might find that your pillage is bringing cities to decline.The other mechanics in the game do not present any remarkable point, but been able to have old school ship fight is quite amusing, as well as deciding your batles by your favorite method of combat (ship/sword fight). The graphics and sound are alright and there is no plot, you make your own history.This game deserves a 10 for the great interaction mechanic it carries even being decades old! Definitely a gap to be yet filled.

content:
ry 23, 2014
												Sid Meier's Pirates! is a surprisingly fun and deep simulation of being a ship captain in the Caribbean during the glory days of piracy. You're not limited to being a pirate. Although the game doesn't explicitly say so, the simulation of the four major powers and two minor powers operating in the Caribbean is quite complex. There's a real war going on, and all of it happens by sea. Although invasions happen over land, troops don't get into position to invade unless they're transported by ship. Many troops don't get paid and people don't get fed unless their wages and food arrive by sea. The economy is primarily based on sea trade, and blockades occur. Warships must be built and sailed where they're needed. And governors and other important people move around by ship.All this means that there's a rich environment for you to play in, and many possibilities for how you want to play. You can, of course, be a pirate and loot the treasure ships of all the wealthy nations. You can serve a nation as a legitimate but independent privateer. You can pretend to be part of a nation's navy and go to war on its behalf, attacking targets of military importance and earning the appreciation of the nation even if you don't get much money out of it. You can even take part in land-based invasions and try to conquer cities, either for the benefit of a nation - territory really changes hands in this game - or just to loot and pillage. Or you can be a peaceful trader. The lesser powers, pirates and Indians (i.e. Native Americans), have their own agendas which enrich the environment further.Besides the sandbox gameplay, you have several concrete goals: rescue your family, acquire wealth and fame, woo beautiful women, find hidden treasure and lost cities, bring villains to justice, and defeat the top pirates in the Caribbean. There are also minor quests that allow you to act as a law enforcer (or turn a blind eye to crime in exchange for bribes, if you wish), and mini-games such as breaking into enemy towns, dancing (which is quite fun), and both real-time combat at sea and turn-based combat on land.There's a lot to do, and for the most part it's all well-designed. There are five difficulty levels, allowing the game to be enjoyable for all players, and several eras you can start in and skills you can specialize in, which increase replay value. The game's main shortcoming is that it's too easy, because it helpfully auto-saves before anything bad happens, allowing you to simply reload your game and retry. This diminishes the importance of many gameplay elements, such as breaking out of jail, upgrading your character, and maintaining multiple ships in your fleet, and leads to excessive risk-taking while dampening the thrill of success. The game really needs an Iron Man mode. (Thankfully, a mod to add one exists.)Another potential problem for some players is that the game doesn't have much of a tutorial, but the manual is good and worth reading.

content:
2014
												When I picked this game up, I had been having this urge to play a pirate game. Something open world, where I could choose my own path, but still be a pirate. I wanted the game to be about more than just continual swordfights. As I looked over the community reviews on various "pirate" games, there didn't seem to be a lot out there that offered open world freedom.Sid Meier's Pirates! offer you that freedom. You can determine the size of your crew, the routes you travel, even who you fight: you are offered the chance to be a privateer for any of 4 different countries (Don't worry, you don't have to serve any allegiance). You also get to decide if you will be the pirate that raids ships and pillage towns for a living, or more of a merchant/pirate that buys and sells goods as well. There is a main questline of finding your long lost family and getting revenge against those responsible, but it doesn't get in the way of any other path you choose.Now, Sid Meier's Pirates! isn't perfect. Some of the minigames get very VERY tedious the ninth or tenth time you do them (dancing with the governor's daughter). But all around, this is a very fun game. And for it's price, this game was definitely worth it, especially for those of you looking to scratch that Pirate itch.

content:
5, 2014
												Sid Meier's Pirates is one of his best games, alongside Civilization 4 and Civ 5. In this game you can experience the exciting world of the 18th century Caribbean, filled with notorious pirates like Blackbeard, buried treasure, and devastating storms to blow you off course. There are two basic ways you can play the game: You can plunder every single penny from every single person, or you can obey every law there is, and befriend the governor of every town and city on the map. And, of course, you can be somewhere in between. This game has one drawback I will mention: you must have a number pad on your keyboard to play it. Almost everything from sailing your ship to the swordfighting minigames requires the number pad. Aside from that limitation, it is a great game. Not too difficult, but not too easy. I recommend that you purchase this game and try it out for yourself. If you like Sid Meier's other games and you like pirates, you'll like this.

content:
13, 2014
												Sid Meier has made many games with clever tactical depth, but is not so swollen with rules, so that anybody can jump right in. Pirates! continues the tradition by being a game chock full of strategy, but is highly accessible.The game is a sandbox. You can go anywhere, and do anything, within the Spanish Main. Generally, you plunder ships or towns, and get promoted by friendly nations. There are plenty of other things to do, too.Tasks you perform have an associated action oriented mini-game. You'll be ship-to-ship battling and swordfighting a lot. I like most of these games, though your mileage may vary. Many people have mixed feelings about them.As far as management goes, the game cuts out micro-managing. The action just keeps flowing. The typical mundane busy work of hard-core strategy games is kindly removed here, in order to get to the good bits. There are plenty of strategic decisions to be made, but you get to think in a sense of what you WANT to do, not what you HAVE to do.Certain things are a little tricky to get used to. Sailing East is much harder than sailing West. Your crew slowly becomes restless over time, forcing you to pay them off and take a few months vacation before going back to sailing.After you get to the ripe old age of about 35, your health starts to decline, and you might have to retire before too long. This takes you to an amusing detailed report on your post-pirate life. Hopefully you are a Governor instead of a Pauper!The graphics and sound are cartoony. Everything looks like it's from a Disney/Pixar movie, and the voice acting is done in jibberish, like in The Sims. Subtitles are in English, though. The cartoony feel is not bad, but is sometimes just a little TOO campy.The controls are a bit strange. While you can use a mouse, you're better off doing the mini-games using the numpad. It's a little awkward at first, but you get used to it fairly soon.Pirates! is one of my all time favorite games. Two thumbs and a wooden peg-leg up!

content:
ber 22, 2013
												Pirates! is a game I played quite a bit in college, and playing it again now, it holds up surprisingly well. You play as a Caribbean pirate in a small ship, and you can use it to build up a huge fleet, earn a fortune, find lost cities of gold, and do tons of other things. More than anything else, Pirates! is a sandbox game. It will suggest things to do, but you're free to set your own goals.When you're not sailing, most of the Pirates! gameplay is in the form of mini-games. You'll become very familiar with Fencing... your sword will solve many problems. But you can also participate in naval combat, dance, siege towns, sneak into hostile towns, or hune around the wilderness for treasure. Most of them are short, simple, skill-based games that are incredibly easy on low difficulties, but can get near impossible on the higher ones.The graphics were good for their time, and they've held up better than I expected. The music is nice, but there's not enough of it. The game usually controls well enough.I got this game when it went on sale, and I've been having a lot of fun with it again. I'd wait for a sale to get Pirates!, but when it does, this is a game worth getting.

content:
, 2014
												For a game that's over ten years old, Pirates is easily the best game I've played in a long time.  It brings a romanticized view of a century of piracy to gaming, yet avoids Treasure Island clichés like parrots and peg legs.  You'll find a lot of light comedy in the presentation of the game, too!  However, the overall gameplay is quite sophisticated.  Unlike games such as Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag, you have to know how to sail with the wind to your advantage.  The size of your sword, ship, and crew matter tremendously as you conquer the West Indies, as well as the hearts of colonial governors' daughters.  You may find yourself chasing ships for game days on end only to lose it to the wind, so you have to be good at assessing situations and using them to your advantage, else the enemy does the same.  Surprisingly, these elements do not detract from the gameplay, but instead add a level of interest and challenge that draws you in further.I'd give it a 9.8out of 10.  It's not perfect, but it's damn close.  My only concern is technical issues (performance), as the game did not run optimally on my system due to the game's slightly antiquated nature.  Even so, the fact that the game IS so old (and this one was a remake) stands as testament to its fantastic ability to entertain.  Any PC gamer should definitely give it a try.

content:
6, 2012
												Sid Meier's Pirates! is a 2005 remake of the original game he made back in the 1980s. This time, you have better graphics, more advanced swordfighting sequences and more options for everything. You start the game off by leading a mutiny on a merchant vessel. From there on, you can decide whether you want to avenge your family by defeating the Marquis de Montalban, defeating all the major pirate captains in the Spanish Main, accumulate vast amounts of wealth through trade, marry a governor's daughter whether she be sexy or ugly, or if you want to attack merchant ships, plunder seaports and instigate a brand new war. The choice is yours! My only complaint is that you can't customize your character: although he does age, you always have to be the Orlando Bloom type of character. Beyond that, this game is every sandbox adventure you ever dreamed of.

content:
13, 2014
												Sid Meier has made many games with clever tactical depth, but is not so swollen with rules, so that anybody can jump right in. Pirates! continues the tradition by being a game chock full of strategy, but is highly accessible.The game is a sandbox. You can go anywhere, and do anything, within the Spanish Main. Generally, you plunder ships or towns, and get promoted by friendly nations. There are plenty of other things to do, too.Tasks you perform have an associated action oriented mini-game. You'll be ship-to-ship battling and swordfighting a lot. I like most of these games, though your mileage may vary. Many people have mixed feelings about them.As far as management goes, the game cuts out micro-managing. The action just keeps flowing. The typical mundane busy work of hard-core strategy games is kindly removed here, in order to get to the good bits. There are plenty of strategic decisions to be made, but you get to think in a sense of what you WANT to do, not what you HAVE to do.Certain things are a little tricky to get used to. Sailing East is much harder than sailing West. Your crew slowly becomes restless over time, forcing you to pay them off and take a few months vacation before going back to sailing.After you get to the ripe old age of about 35, your health starts to decline, and you might have to retire before too long. This takes you to an amusing detailed report on your post-pirate life. Hopefully you are a Governor instead of a Pauper!The graphics and sound are cartoony. Everything looks like it's from a Disney/Pixar movie, and the voice acting is done in jibberish, like in The Sims. Subtitles are in English, though. The cartoony feel is not bad, but is sometimes just a little TOO campy.The controls are a bit strange. While you can use a mouse, you're better off doing the mini-games using the numpad. It's a little awkward at first, but you get used to it fairly soon.Pirates! is one of my all time favorite games. Two thumbs and a wooden peg-leg up!

												I rank the 1987 version of this game as one of my favorite gaming experiences ever (eventhough it took an eternity to start on my c64 cassette-player). I've also played the 1994 version, which was more or less identical to the first, apart from then up to date grafics and sound. So it was with mixed emotions that I aproached this installment of Pirates. Would it hold up, would my memories be bashed to pieces, would I be tormented by nightmares of spanish pirate hunters? Well I'm surprised to say that it did hold up, petty well. Most of the orginal gameplay was still there, basically the same ship combat, basically the same melee (3 attacks, 3 parries/evades), The "new" stuff like added items, new settlement types, new city-combat all added to the gameplay in a good way, the dancing maybe not so much though. Although the grafics is now outdated, they do give a nice cartoonish feel to the game.Basically this is the same game that a loved as a kid, but with an added delicate facelift.

You sail around the Carribean and capture ships (or even cities!) of the other nations. You can fight pirates too, including some of the famous ones! Combat involves primarily dueling where you could your opponent's sword move and attack with your own. You may also utilize ship based naval combat by firing off your cannons against other ships with 3 different kinds of shots: your general damage round shot, grape shot to take down crew members, or chain shot to bring down masts & sails. Aside from the combat your goal is to defeat the baddies, gain treasure maps, rescue family members, and even settle down with a lovely wife! =)Bottom line: play it, but ♥♥♥♥ sailing east.

content:
r 15, 2011
												This is a terrificly fun, low stress game that gives you the sights and sounds of being a pirate in the caribbean seas circa the 1600's. It plays out like a fast paced board game crossed with an enthusiastic child's fanciful imaginings of the piratey life: all of the highs and none of the lows. It's such a breath of fresh air to play a game that doesn't try to saddle you with a heavy "Hollywood" cinematic story. The encounters are entirely under your control in true sandbox style and you venture through a series of minigames at different locations to obtain information about the placement of notable people, treasures, and upgrades, with each task being fun and easy to grasp.  There's a wealth of things to do with the only drawback being repetition sets in too early; you fight the same pirates, perform the same battle actions, talk to the same placeholder figures over and over again. Give it a shot.  It's fun and frivolous and you'll definintely be entertained.

content:
ry 23, 2014
												Sid Meier's Pirates! is a surprisingly fun and deep simulation of being a ship captain in the Caribbean during the glory days of piracy. You're not limited to being a pirate. Although the game doesn't explicitly say so, the simulation of the four major powers and two minor powers operating in the Caribbean is quite complex. There's a real war going on, and all of it happens by sea. Although invasions happen over land, troops don't get into position to invade unless they're transported by ship. Many troops don't get paid and people don't get fed unless their wages and food arrive by sea. The economy is primarily based on sea trade, and blockades occur. Warships must be built and sailed where they're needed. And governors and other important people move around by ship.All this means that there's a rich environment for you to play in, and many possibilities for how you want to play. You can, of course, be a pirate and loot the treasure ships of all the wealthy nations. You can serve a nation as a legitimate but independent privateer. You can pretend to be part of a nation's navy and go to war on its behalf, attacking targets of military importance and earning the appreciation of the nation even if you don't get much money out of it. You can even take part in land-based invasions and try to conquer cities, either for the benefit of a nation - territory really changes hands in this game - or just to loot and pillage. Or you can be a peaceful trader. The lesser powers, pirates and Indians (i.e. Native Americans), have their own agendas which enrich the environment further.Besides the sandbox gameplay, you have several concrete goals: rescue your family, acquire wealth and fame, woo beautiful women, find hidden treasure and lost cities, bring villains to justice, and defeat the top pirates in the Caribbean. There are also minor quests that allow you to act as a law enforcer (or turn a blind eye to crime in exchange for bribes, if you wish), and mini-games such as breaking into enemy towns, dancing (which is quite fun), and both real-time combat at sea and turn-based combat on land.There's a lot to do, and for the most part it's all well-designed. There are five difficulty levels, allowing the game to be enjoyable for all players, and several eras you can start in and skills you can specialize in, which increase replay value. The game's main shortcoming is that it's too easy, because it helpfully auto-saves before anything bad happens, allowing you to simply reload your game and retry. This diminishes the importance of many gameplay elements, such as breaking out of jail, upgrading your character, and maintaining multiple ships in your fleet, and leads to excessive risk-taking while dampening the thrill of success. The game really needs an Iron Man mode. (Thankfully, a mod to add one exists.)Another potential problem for some players is that the game doesn't have much of a tutorial, but the manual is good and worth reading.

content:
2014
												When I picked this game up, I had been having this urge to play a pirate game. Something open world, where I could choose my own path, but still be a pirate. I wanted the game to be about more than just continual swordfights. As I looked over the community reviews on various "pirate" games, there didn't seem to be a lot out there that offered open world freedom.Sid Meier's Pirates! offer you that freedom. You can determine the size of your crew, the routes you travel, even who you fight: you are offered the chance to be a privateer for any of 4 different countries (Don't worry, you don't have to serve any allegiance). You also get to decide if you will be the pirate that raids ships and pillage towns for a living, or more of a merchant/pirate that buys and sells goods as well. There is a main questline of finding your long lost family and getting revenge against those responsible, but it doesn't get in the way of any other path you choose.Now, Sid Meier's Pirates! isn't perfect. Some of the minigames get very VERY tedious the ninth or tenth time you do them (dancing with the governor's daughter). But all around, this is a very fun game. And for it's price, this game was definitely worth it, especially for those of you looking to scratch that Pirate itch.

content:
5, 2014
												Sid Meier's Pirates is one of his best games, alongside Civilization 4 and Civ 5. In this game you can experience the exciting world of the 18th century Caribbean, filled with notorious pirates like Blackbeard, buried treasure, and devastating storms to blow you off course. There are two basic ways you can play the game: You can plunder every single penny from every single person, or you can obey every law there is, and befriend the governor of every town and city on the map. And, of course, you can be somewhere in between. This game has one drawback I will mention: you must have a number pad on your keyboard to play it. Almost everything from sailing your ship to the swordfighting minigames requires the number pad. Aside from that limitation, it is a great game. Not too difficult, but not too easy. I recommend that you purchase this game and try it out for yourself. If you like Sid Meier's other games and you like pirates, you'll like this.

content:

												Sid Meier's Pirates! is a 2005 remake of the original game he made back in the 1980s. This time, you have better graphics, more advanced swordfighting sequences and more options for everything. You start the game off by leading a mutiny on a merchant vessel. From there on, you can decide whether you want to avenge your family by defeating the Marquis de Montalban, defeating all the major pirate captains in the Spanish Main, accumulate vast amounts of wealth through trade, marry a governor's daughter whether she be sexy or ugly, or if you want to attack merchant ships, plunder seaports and instigate a brand new war. The choice is yours! My only complaint is that you can't customize your character: although he does age, you always have to be the Orlando Bloom type of character. Beyond that, this game is every sandbox adventure you ever dreamed of.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
5, 2014
												Sid Meier's Pirates is one of his best games, alongside Civilization 4 and Civ 5. In this game you can experience the exciting world of the 18th century Caribbean, filled with notorious pirates like Blackbeard, buried treasure, and devastating storms to blow you off course. There are two basic ways you can play the game: You can plunder every single penny from every single person, or you can obey every law there is, and befriend the governor of every town and city on the map. And, of course, you can be somewhere in between. This game has one drawback I will mention: you must have a number pad on your keyboard to play it. Almost everything from sailing your ship to the swordfighting minigames requires the number pad. Aside from that limitation, it is a great game. Not too difficult, but not too easy. I recommend that you purchase this game and try it out for yourself. If you like Sid Meier's other games and you like pirates, you'll like this.

ry 24, 2015
												This is a remake of the original from the late 80s (was it early 90s?). It uses the same engine as civ4 and overall does a pretty nice job. You'll love it whether you've played pirates before or not.The sea combat is great, land combat is ok, but drastically improved over the original. Duels are a tad too scripted and easy but get the job done.The dances mini game for wooing potential mates is kind of annoying but it works ok. What doesn't work and what sucks in this game is sneaking into cities. It's a really slow stealth crawl through town and very hard to find the building you are looking for. Dreadful, just try to avoid sneaking around. As in all the other pirates games search for lost treasure at times can be really difficult but it shouldn't be too easy right?Overall I had a great time trying to collect everything in one playthrough. It's so open ended that once you collect everything there isn't a ton of point in replaying but it does have replay value if just like the gameplay.

content:
3, 2014
												So basically this is a pirate simulator. You start out as a young guy with a small crew and ship. Years ago an evil pirate breaks up your family leaving you alone and now you're matured you set out on the Caribbean. From there you choose to follow the storyline of getting your family back OR disregard that and lead the life of a stereotypical pirate.Gameplay is a little limited BUT there's a lot of paths you can go. By paths I mean you can choose which time period to live in, choose what life you want to lead, choose whom you ally with (or be a total pirate), a great selection of ships (all customizeable), your personal skill sets. The limited part is that for most of the time you'll be doing the same thing: get a  ship, go plunder other ships, sell items, get gold, talk to people in the town. There's some side things like rescuing people, helping a country out, collecting treasure maps but generally it's the same thing regardless of which path you go.The visuals are very colourful and beautiful. Although the game is old the visuals have a style that still looks good and not dated. The sound is great. The music, although limited to a few key tunes, is very pirate styled and pleasing.So in short although the game is somewhat limited in what you can do it doesn't get boring over time! That's because it is quite immersive, aesthetic, controls well and is just fun! Beautiful graphics and audio and good controls ensure this game doesn't feel dated.7/10

content:
29, 2014
												If ye be looking fer' Pirates, you surely found them with this scurvy old title. Clean as a captain's spyglass is the play of the ships and friendly enough fer' lads and lasses of all ages ta' enjoy. Ye be starting with a measly sloop and the entire Carribean be at yer' call. Chase after ye lost family or sack some french ports and marry the Governer's daughter. Pirates be as timeless as the sea herself, an' for just 10 pieces of eight, she be right for the remembering. Yar.Horrible attempts at pirate talk aside, this is by far one of the best games I've ever enjoyed playing. I can remember back when Sid Meier's Pirates had just been released how many endless days were spent sitting in front of my computer screen playing the wars between England and Spain. It's got a special place in my heart.The game plays out as an open-world sandbox where one is free to pursue the noble goals of taking down the top ten most notorious pirates of the carribean and sacking ports. Or if one is feeling a bit less like fighting they can play the relatively simple merchant game of buying goods in one port and sailing them to another for profit. There is the ever present staple of pirate tales where buried treasure maps can be found. Also this portion of the game around your entire family being kidnapped and you needing to rescue them, there's that. However Pirates never directly forces you to do anything. It is a sandbox in the truest sense, at least under all of that water. Ships can be upgraded at the different ports and while learning the map comes naturally you won't be stuck going to the same 4 ports over and over (Unless you choose to, that is.)The combat element plays out in one of four ways. The naval battles between ship and ship feel crisp and polished even despite the game's age. While rudimentery in some ways, ships bombard eachother with broadsides of roundshot, grapeshot, or chainshot. Once enough damage has been dealt or if taking the ship is the goal the ramming of the two ships together will start the swordplay. Swordplay consists of three attacks, three dodges, and one taunt. While basic it is entirely about timing and plays out fairly well. There is a turn-based strategy portion to sacking a port with a landing party but my strategy in this has always been to simply bring more men. The only place where the game falls short is in it's Stealth selection of sneaking into a hostile port. It's not bad, but it does feel a bit slow and very repetitive.Out of all the games I've played or purchased on steam through either my own library or familyshare, this one is by far the best Game-Per-Cash value. At $9.99 it's nice to see a familiar old face pop back up and give me hours of good natured fun. I can't reccomend it enough.

												My wife and I love this game so much we decided to make a let's play - who knew a game this old could still keep us hooked after all these years?   I love this game, my wife loves it, my kids love it, even my father in law played for hundreds of ours.  It's appropriate - and fun- for all ages.The combat is simplified, easy and very satisfying - the story is simple and satisfying, the graphics are still beautiful and compare to many modern indie games out there.  Actually now that I think of it, this was one of the first non dungeon rogue like games to come out.  Every game is different and you never know where the seas will take you.Highly recommended and we'd love to connect with other Sid Meier's Pirates players out there!Here is my wife and I playing what we call a thirty minute pirate game

Whilst not bowled over entirely, this game IS very addictive, and I played it for several long, intensive sessions; certainly getting good value for money in the process.What we have here is more a collection of minigames than anything else; hotkey-based swordplay and dancing, a very detailed sailing simulator (albeit an easy one), and some grid-based TBS thrown in for good measure if you decide to take your crew ashore to plunder a town.A good game, but with limited replayabiility as you tend to find the "optimum" build very quickly.  I'd pay £5 for this game.

content:
ry 22, 2014
												Sid Meier's Pirates another great game from a great game maker. Your family is taken for ransom, you grow to be a teenager and you are ready to set sail to try to free your enslaved family from the evil Colonel.Or you can say SCREW THAT, IMA GO PLUNDER SOME SHIPS!!! You are free to do so :)This is a pirate-sandbox game. Similar to the newly released Pirate Game, Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag. You can follow the storyline and set free your enslaved family, or you could go out to sea and plunder, get yourself married to a governer's daughter, gather the ships of Blackbeard, Black Bart, and Captain Morgan, upgrade them to their highest, THEN go out and rescue them. This is what I like about Sid Meier's games, its got good sandbox engine to it. The Carribean is HUGE, you could sail for hours and maybe not even get 100% of the content done.The Melee combat is fluid, but a little TOO easy. Just counter when the button flashes, then attack. The ship combat is fun as well, although its very trivial if compared to Black Flag. If you wish to go save your family and THEN take down famous pirates, feel free to do so! It is important to note that you should not split your loot until you feel you are ready to do so, because you will lose some ships and loot and you need all the loot you can get since upgrades and items are expensive, but it makes it so money HAS a use at least. Unlike Black Flag, this game requires you make an effort to keep your ship in good condition and your crew happy, if your crew gets unhappy, they will abandon you. You dont want that.As I said, the Carribean is huge, but honestly in this game, Its kind of TOO big. Black Flag has a function where you can initiate Travel Speed and get where you need to go faster. This game only has half and full sails, and even then, if you dont follow the wind direction, your not gonna get anywhere in the next 5-10 minutes. It should also be worth mentioning that you do NOT have any sort of waypoint system in this game. You have to navigate your way around, which can be a bit difficult, but if your patient, you'll start getting it.So, is this game good? Yes! This is for you if you absolutely love the Golden Age of Piracy and want to experience it in a way.

												This game is like 5 games in one: sailing, real time ship battles, fencing, turn based strategy, dancing (Rhythm game), and more. Stick with me here though: what makes classic nintendo games great, is that they are simple enough for a newbie to pick up and enjoy but also evolving with enough depth to grasp a hardcore gamer. THIS IS THAT TYPE OF GAME and what makes Pirates! so great as well. Start out as an apprentice -each time your crew is unhappy, divide the plunder to start refresh and jump to the next diffculty level. The game really progresses from each tier of diffculty nicely til your at the most difficult level and you are like wow, how did this game get to this point, it was so easy at first. The graphics still hold up too! Play this now! Trust me, there is something for everyone in this game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
26, 2015
												(This is the 2004 remake of the original game from 1987). Sid Meier's Pirates is a lighthearted swashbuckling romp set during the Age of Discovery.The gameplay basically boils down to a series of minigames; ship-to-ship battles, sword duels, dancing, land battles and treasure hunts.The game is open-ended; there's a 'main quest' of sorts but you can feel free to ignore it if you want. There's plenty of other goals to pursue; find buried treasure, defeat infamous pirates to become the most feared in the Caribbean, track down wanted criminals and collect their bounties, escort ships carrying peace treaties (or betray the nation you're helping and destroy them - war is more profitable than peace for a pirate after all) or just attack everything in sight and amass as much loot as you can.A game won't last forever - your pirate starts the game aged 18 and as time passes in the game he will age and eventually be forced into retirement. If this game has an overall "goal" at all it's to have the highest score you can at the time you retire. The game has difficulty levels; on every playthrough after your first you can choose between them - first time starting a new game, you're forced into the easiest difficulty, though there's a way to change it once you get going, too.Unfortunately, I don't feel like the game has much replay value. The minigames (with the exception of ship battles) are repetitive and shallow and I was burned out on the game before I'd seen everything it had to offer (I completed the "main quest", went after all the named pirates and then lost interest). The harder difficulty settings feel more frustrating than genuinely challenging, too.Still, I got 25 hours of fun out of this game for £6, so I'd say I got my money's worth; I recommend it.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
2015
												I like this game but the age really limits it's mechanics. It becomes very samey after a few hours. I feel like if there was a sequel to this game made today, it would be really great. So ill list all the bad points first.-Ship travel is often SLOW as hell. Especially if you have to travel against the wind (which never changes direction). It could have done with a minimum speed cap based on the ship you have.-Basic sword fighting. The sword fights are all the same and are quickly cheesed with fast attacks.-Not much to do. You can marry a daughter (one), Kill 9 other pirates, rank up with each faction, tresure hunt, and do  the main story line. Sounds like a lot on paper but then you realize killing pirates are the same as fighting any other person in the game, Ranking up is exactly the same in each faction, each daughter requires the same exact things, and the main story is mostly more pirate hunting stuff. Its extremly limited in variation.-There really isnt much of a story anyway. Its got open world-itus which means you can go anywhere at anytime but there isnt any structure. The pacing is god awful. and it takes forever to get to the next story point. In the 6 hours I have played (never played it before) I got to the highest rank in the english faction as well as midway in the other 3, killed all other 9 pirates, had married a daughter and romanced 4 others high enough to marry if I wasnt already, Saved 3 family members in the main story (which involves killing the SAME guy over and over) and gotten most of the items in the game.All that said though, I did enjoy myself for the most part. The only part I really hated was just how slow ship travel is which would entail me watching a video on another screen while my ship traveled across the map for 10 minutes. I do think its worth picking up if its on sale for very cheap and I do think you will have a decent time with it for a few hours.Its just held back due to the time period it was released in. Unfortunatley the mechanics dont hold up as well in this day and age. Im surprised a sequel hasnt been made yet seeing the love for the ship battles in Assassins Creed Black Flag though. I feel like it would do wonderfully in the market right now.

content:
21, 2015
												Where to start..... Unlike alot of these reviewers, i had not played this before, i walked into this game completely blind. So, the fact that theres no nostaligia involved here, my review is for those who have never played or heard of this game before. Theres no tutorial or manual to speak of, but to be honest this game dosnt really need one. Its an rpg, so if youve palyed previous rpgs like me, you'll have a basic understanding of what your doing. If you havnt played one before then this would be an excellent first choice. So, your thrust into this open world pirate game with nothing but a back story, which i might add is not narrated in the slightest. In fact, i think the reason theres so much content in this game is because they didnt do any voice acting AT ALL. Theres just mostly grunts or the wooing of ladies for "dialog". But besides the lack of voice acting, the game is damn near perfect. There is SO much to do in this world. Without any spoilers, You have to save your family, become a top notch pirate, track down criminals, defeat pirates based off of real life ones such as Captain Kidd and Black Beard, pillage ships, raids towns, dance with the ladies, ship battles, fleet managments, sell plunder, buy food stocks, get unique items, upgrade your ship, get special crew members, conquer cities in a board game like rts mode, search for buried treasure, get promotions, gain land, ect. And thats probably half of what there is. At this point im only 10 hours in the game and i have already done all of that, and there is just so much more to do. If your a fan of pirates or Rpgs, GET THIS GAME AND GET IT NOW!!! It's only 10 dollars for so so SO much content, and the replayability is off the charts! Do yourself a favor, and buy this game and pray they make another one!

content:
12, 2015
												Let me start off by saying that I love this game so much that I almost felt like I was cheating on my wife when I bought it anew last night. I bought it on the day that it originally came out, and spent actual DAYS playing the game, only stopping to eat, bathe, and go to the bathroom. I don't think that I slept more than eight total hours in that first week, and my name was known, loved, and feared throughout the Caribbean. More so than in any other Sid Meier game before or since, I was completely engulfed by this game to the point of addiction.Then, you know, life (and other games) happened.So, flash forward a few years and I saw that it was on Steam. How well did it hold up? Would I fire it up, laugh at the dated gfx and gameplay, never to play again? Would it be like I'd never stopped playing and find myself engulfed into the game again? I downloaded it last night, and have already racked up seven, almost eight hours. Gfx and some clunky and (now) counter-intuitive gameplay aside, I still love this game and thought it was absolutely worth the $10 to buy it again. It's just as fun as I remembered, although I do confess that I still hate the dancing portion of the game! Absolutely recommended!My only REAL gripe is with the sound. It's not that it's dated, it's just that when you're playing the game, you have no choice but to either turn off the sound altogether OR you're forced to listen to the same... jaunty... pirate... ditties... again... and... again... and... Imagine being forced to listen to the sound of a dentist's drill or your favorite child's death rattle on infinite loop - this is the quality of the music. While you can go into the system properties and turn off the music, that's only the music for cut scenes and the like - the in-game music is tied irrevokably to the sound effects, so no cannonfire, no sound of the wind... unless you're willing to listen to monkey-grinder music.

A classic. One of my favorite games of all time.Personal overall rating: 9/10I've played this game for almost 9 years now! Just got it on my computer a few days ago and, wow... It's so much better. I first played it on Xbox, then psp, then got it for my 360, and now have it for my computer. Of course, this is the best version of the game. ALL HAIL THE MASTER RACEOPTIONS MENU:The Video settings has 9 options. Picture Gamma, Water Detail, Object Detail, World Detail, Resolution, Shadows, Advanced Lighting, Trillinear Filtering, & Shaders. It's an old game, most computers will be able to handle it with the settings turned up relatively high. The Audio Settings has a Master Volume slider, Music Volume, Sound FX Volume, Dance Music Volume, and a 3D Sound Driver toggle. The Modify Ship's Sails and Flags option changes your ship's flag appearance and the logo/crest on your main sail. There's 6 crests/logos for your sail. 1.Dutch: Greater Coat of Arms of The Netherlands, 2.English: St George Crest, 3.French: Royal Coat of Arms of The Kingdom of France, 4.Indians: Tribal Tiki Logo, 5.Pirates: Jolly Roger Crest, 6.Spanish: Coat of Arms of Toledo.There are 5 flags, the Flags are 1.Dutch: Orange flag with a green xing emblem, 2.English: White flag with a red St George cross, 3.French: Blue flag with a gold Flour De Les emblem. 4.Pirates: Black flag with a white Jolly Roger. 5.Spanish: Yellow flag with a black Royal Lion. GRAPHICS:It's an old game. It's not exactly pretty. The game looks best while you're out sailing. There is noticeable aliasing, mushy textures, and choppy animations. The water refelction is decent. The explosion effect during ship battles when cannonballs make contact and when ships explode is awesome. It's the game's strongest point graphically. The way the colors of the sea blend together is nice as well. STORY:The story is kind of weird. An evil Spanish nobleman (the Marquis de la Montalbán) interupts a dinner party consisting of you and your family. Your family is in debt to him. When you see him, you immediatley know he has bad intentions, so you bolt passed him through the door. He takes your family. They become slaves. You survive on your own for the next 10 years. You begin your young adulthood joining a faction (Dutch, English, French, or Spanish). You serve on a ship where a cruel captain is in charge. Tired of being abused and insulted by the captain, you and your mates rally up and form a mutiny against him. You boot him from the ship, and take charge. You're the captain now, and realize this is the perfect opportunity to find your lost family. PLAYING THE GAME:Sailing is a ton of fun. The feeling of adventure you get from cruising the sea is so satisfying. Playing a game that isn't the same copy paste recipe as every other game in itself is extremely satisfying. There's open sea adventure, epic ship battles, duels, city invasions, sneaking through hostile towns, treasure hunting, pirate hunting, and the wonderful ability to do whatever you want. Live the pirate life your way. You can gain new items for your character like dual pistols and some well crafted swords. You can aquire new ships and give them upgrades. You can even name your ships as well as your character of course. You'll be addressed by your character's name by the other people in the game. They address you by your surname, so when creating your character make sure you name them by their last name. Anyways but yea, that's the game. You build up your crew, and become the deadliest pirate to ever live. Please try the game. It's cheap, it's fun. You'll enjoy it. Please just try it.

content:
20, 2015
												Why is this game so good? If you look at it from an objective PoV, this is just a collection of repetitive minigames (there's a swordfighting, which is basically a rythm game; Dancing, which is literally a rythm game; Theres a siege which has some strategical options but basically coes down to "more troops win"; And a naval battle which becomes somewhat boring as you realize the AI is really dumb at it). On the top of it all is a fairly simple resource management system (basically, have food) and "get from point A to point B" system which is a slog, especially if you are travelling from west to east.This doesnt sound too good now, does it. So why is this game so good? I played the heck out of the original about 20 years ago on a Commodore64, and again about 10 years ago when this version came out. And yesterday I bought the Steam version and I just wanted to fire it up for a while to see how it runs, and then somehow I played almost 8 hours straight without even moving from my chair or noticing the time.During that 8 hours, I - raided countless ships - Always showed mercy to the lads who wanted to come aboard- became the most notorious pirate on the entire spanish main- Found Blackbeard's legendary buried treasure between a tree with a dead man hanging and an Inca temple- Sacked Havana twice- elected a dutch govenor there - Found out the new govenor's daughter is actually beautiful- became pretty good at pressing buttons while dancing- I fenced with her fincée- Then I rescued her from captivity - and married her (which turned out was a pretty bad idea since traveling from Havana to anywhere is actually a slugfest)- I found two of my long- lost relatives - kicked the ♥♥♥♥ of Evil Baron Raymondo a dozen times - defeated the long-standing enemy of my family Marquis Montalban (who is now my cabin boy) - and found the legendary lost city of the Incas.So there you have it. I think the strongpoints of the game is the athmosphere, living the pirate dream, and all the stories you make up for yourself. The game has a really vibrant world and the sandbox frame lets you fill it with your own stories. And of course there is that "just lets dig up this one more treasure then I'll go to sleep for real" vibe.Tow remarks at the end, one: For some reason the FPS drops if you fire with anything other than normal cannonballs. Second: I can kinda recommend this game for kids. There is some non- depicted killling during battles, but there is no violence or gore during swordfights. Also there are some big blossoms but no nudity. The atmoshpere is bright and the game is simple to play.

content:
21, 2015
												Where to start..... Unlike alot of these reviewers, i had not played this before, i walked into this game completely blind. So, the fact that theres no nostaligia involved here, my review is for those who have never played or heard of this game before. Theres no tutorial or manual to speak of, but to be honest this game dosnt really need one. Its an rpg, so if youve palyed previous rpgs like me, you'll have a basic understanding of what your doing. If you havnt played one before then this would be an excellent first choice. So, your thrust into this open world pirate game with nothing but a back story, which i might add is not narrated in the slightest. In fact, i think the reason theres so much content in this game is because they didnt do any voice acting AT ALL. Theres just mostly grunts or the wooing of ladies for "dialog". But besides the lack of voice acting, the game is damn near perfect. There is SO much to do in this world. Without any spoilers, You have to save your family, become a top notch pirate, track down criminals, defeat pirates based off of real life ones such as Captain Kidd and Black Beard, pillage ships, raids towns, dance with the ladies, ship battles, fleet managments, sell plunder, buy food stocks, get unique items, upgrade your ship, get special crew members, conquer cities in a board game like rts mode, search for buried treasure, get promotions, gain land, ect. And thats probably half of what there is. At this point im only 10 hours in the game and i have already done all of that, and there is just so much more to do. If your a fan of pirates or Rpgs, GET THIS GAME AND GET IT NOW!!! It's only 10 dollars for so so SO much content, and the replayability is off the charts! Do yourself a favor, and buy this game and pray they make another one!

content:
, 2014
												This is one of the best pirate themed video games ever made, and the game that most pirate themed games end up taking their inspiration from. It's easy to pick up and play yet there's a lot of complexity here too. From bounties to allegiances to trading there are a lot of things you can do here yet you can also just sail around capturing ships & pillaging. The main thing I like about this is the fact that no matter what you do you never feel bored. You never run out of stuff to do, and you're always accomplishing stuff. Goals can be challenging but they're never so impossible that they get too frustrating. This is a great title that will challenge you and even if you fail at a challenge it never punishes you for it. It gives you many chances to come back later when you're more prepared for it. All in all one of the best games I've ever played, and certainly one of the best pirate games ever.
