content:
9, 2016
												Disappointing.  I really want to like this game but it has some issues.  There are some bugs that can pop up and make life annoying, such as getting stuck different places in your ship.  For example, I was captured and then bribed my way out of Havana.  My ship ended up on the opposite side of the island, glued to the shore.  No way to get off the beach.  Only thing to do is go to last save point.  I've also been trapped near towns with sand bars near, having to constantly answer the pop up "do you want to anchor or sail away?" while attempting to navigate away in the split second allowed.  Game is really, really simple.  Kind of surprising, given Sid Meier's other games.  Overly simple/devoid of features in many ways.  Can't do anything with land you're granted.  Can't invade enemy towns unless they have a garrison.  Can only attack convoys with one ship at a time, no matter how many ships you have.  Convoy gets all ships.  You can accidentally sell the cannons off your ship and end up defenseless.  If enemies capture a ship of yours, you can't capture it back, it just disappears.

number of helpful: 32 of 85 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
9, 2015
												Though I put quite a few hours into this game my lasting impression is that it's not very enjoyable.  The concept itself is good, but the game becomes very repetitive and the play balance on harder difficulties is completely bonkers.  Late game on Rogue difficulty I lost a ship to only three hits, when fighting other ships of the same type I would hit them twenty times or more before they would sink.  The AI gets special abilities like attacking you on the strategic map, and the late "quests" of endgame are simply finding and fighting the same guy over and over again until you get a map to go and fight him again in some place in the middle of no where. And while the game has a lot of "mini-games", man of these are simply not compelling.   The game has a lot of content but all that content is ultimately light on depth, and despite playing the game to its conclusion and getting a Fame score of 106 my "victory" was little more than a page of text.  Why not a simple cinematic?If you get it cheap, play it, then go on to something with more enduring quality and depth.

number of helpful: 15 of 47 people (32%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 19, 2015
												I heard so much about this game and I love Civilization that I had to try it.  It was meh.  I think nostalgia clouds too many minds on how wonderful this game is.  It's not bad, it just isn't all that special. There isn't a real storyline (they kind of make a basic quest of finding your family which isn't very exciting) and maybe that would have spiced the game up for me.  I love a good story.  It just throws you in there and you just start living the life of a pirate captain which is great if you don't like being shackled to linear game play.  Felt like a chore going back and forth on the map at a snail's pace and I just wasn't having fun.  I gave up after realizing how many times I had to trek back and forth and I didn't want to waste my time with it.  I feel like this would work as a casual game on a mobile device that you could play for a bit, put it down, and pick it up later.  The dancing sequences are annoying, the sword fights are all the same and get boring, and trying to catch the wind in your sails was ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off.  I feel there are more engaging choices out there.

number of helpful: 8 of 31 people (26%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
r 25, 2016
												Hahaha, these upset fangirls.  I guess the truth does hurt.I should've stopped playing this a couple hours in, but I wanted to give the game a chance to get better.  It's too bad that it never does.Let's start with what looks good about this game.  Decent sized world, four nations to work for/against to gain rank, NPC ships attack one another, nations declare war and peace against one another, nations capture each others ports, many types of ships, freedom to do what you want, trading, pirating, making a fleet, sword fighting, romance, treasure hunting, rescuing family, finding lost cities, storms at sea, crew mutinies, bringing down pirates, and even other stuff.  It sounds awesome.  It's too bad most of the things that happen are pointless and half of the game is tedious minigames.I'd say about 50% of your time will be spent playing the minigames, so lets start with them.  There are several minigames including sea battles, sword-fights, dancing, land navigation, sneaking, and ground battles.  Most of the minigames you'll play will be the first three.  They're ok at first, but you'll play those same minigames over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over.  Did you get tired of reading that? That's how I felt about those first three minigames after playing them 15 times.  Then realize in a playthrough that you'll play those three anywhere from 60-100+ times.  Imagine playing Mario Party, except it only has 6 mediocre minigames, and it only selects 3 of those minigames 90% of the time.  Then play that Mario Party for 10-13 hours.  That's what playing through Sid Meier's Pirates feels like.  I have absolutely no idea how anyone could tolerate multiple playthroughs of this mindless dreck.The other 50% of the time spent sailing would've been alright, except for the wind.  Do you like sailing west?  No worries, because the wind has got your back.  At some point though, you're going to need to sail back east.  You will.. do... this.... at.... a.... snail's.... pace.... against.... the.... wind.... Oh... here... comes... a... cloud... to.. speed me back up and.. it's... gone.... Time.... to.... take.... a.... nap....  I hated sailing anywhere in the west.  There were times when I'd set sail east, walk out of the room for a bit, come back, and still not be at my destination.  Nothing interesting ever happens while you're out at sea either.  You'll never be in danger of running out of food.  I often had multiple years worth of food from sacking ships.  I'd go into ports selling it off.  It's cool to see a Treasure Ship or Military Payroll for the first time, but by the 5th time, it's not quite so exciting, and by the 10th time, you won't even bother plundering them unless it keeps your crew from going to mutiny status.  The most exciting thing that happens out on the sea is accidentally running into one of the main quest enemies.  This is only exciting because it saves you 10 minutes of boredom finding out where they're headed and spending time tracking them down.  Also somewhat annoying is that occasionally the game will launch you out of a port straight into some rocks which damage your ship.  If you have a large fleet, instead of following your path, they do their own thing.  This often includes taking damage when they sail into rocks that you manuevered around but they decided would make an excellent path.I could've probably tolerated all of that stuff if the rest of the game made up for it, but it doesn't.  The game has no objective and nothing you do matters.  Doesn't matter whether you save your family, or rank up with each nation, or take out all the top pirates or do anything.  The game ends whenever you feel like it should end and retire.  One nation declares war or peace on another nation, doesn't impact you at all.  NPC ship sinks another npc ship, it'll respawn.  One nation conquers another nation's port, doesn't matter, can still sail in there and do all the same things I could've done anyway.  Pirates sack a port, doesn't matter.  Want to buy some of the cool stuff that guy in the corner sells, crew gets mutinous.  Amass a nice fleet, doesn't matter, only your flagship fights in battles and your crew will become mutinous and you'll have to divide the plunder and go back to 1 ship anyway.  You're the top pirate in the land, doesn't affect a thing.  Saved all your family, does nothing.  Want to save your family?  Have fun hunting down Baron Raymondo and waiting for him to respawn 12-16 times to get all the maps pieces.  Have fun sword fighting that same guy behind the bar 25 times that the dancing minigame gives you as a quest.  I completed most of the main objectives, aside from nation ranks, but gave up and retired when my wife expected me to dance with her 8 more times for the rest of the lost city map pieces.Maybe the problem is that I played Uncharted Waters on the Sega Genesis and know what a good pirate game should be.  This entire game is a tedious grind where nothing you do matters.

content:
y 6, 2016
												It blows my mind how this gets any positive reviews. I suppose everything will have it's lovers and haters. Count me in the latter category.I typically love Sid Miere's games too. NEVER have I run into more outdated controls in my life. Even playing it at moderate difficulty levels I found this "game" to be more stress-inducing than a flight being canceled at the busiest airport while being forced to take two final exams in chemistry and 16th Century Literaure all at the same time. CONS:- The AI will generally always counter your sword attacks, while countering it's own requires PRECISE timing or else. - Adapts and speed up dance challenges, to the point where the odds of winning are slim to none.- You'll generally ALWAYS be placed upwind in ship battles, making manuvering nigh impossible. Meanwhile, AI ships will dance circles around you- The winds tend to blow extremely fast in one direction (west in my experience) making travel in the opposite direction very tedious and time-consuming.PROS:- Immersive, the general atmosphere is great- The music is simple but lovely- Fun, when the difficulty is balanced [usually never] (even at lower difficulties it's an imbalanced game)All in all I can't say I enjoyed my time with this title. In fact, I believe it gave me muscle cramps due to the stress it induced. I'm glad I only spent $2.50 on it during a sale, but I can say it was $2.50 wasted

												I wish ratings was not yes or no. Im giving it a no just because the ratings are too high. See, it is a great game for its time. But theres a few annoying parts. It cant be called an adventure game because you are restricted to the caribean and you do not feel like an adventurer. Not the improved 'uncharted waters' I hoped for. The challenge is too wimpy at first- get your attack speed up and mash buttons in duels to win every battle- then becomes too hard. But most annoying of all there is no tutorials. I have played this long and became #1 pirate, and dont know HTF dueling (the main thing in the game) even works, the controlls seem to suck. Dancing seemed impossibly hard. Granted I am playing as adventurer captain (hard difficulty) but that stuff should have been explained by the time I finished my 6th pirating carreer. You cant really customize your ship. And trading stinks, you really cant make any money at it. For the record I do recommend it anyways if it is on sale.Some things I find quite great is the ship to ship battles take a lot of skill, and has quite a lot of depth. And when you attack a town the game turns into a nearly full strategy game.If I or anyone else could mod the game for even a few months, it would be great. But as is it just slightly below wonderfull, just a collectors item from another time.

content:
er 11, 2014
												So much promise but age and/or operating systems have brought down what Pirates could be.The first problem I encountered was an absolutely ridiculous graphical glitch with the sails and flags of the ships. I would boil it down to a physx issue, but I don’t think that technology even existed when Pirates was released. Basically what would happen is that when the wind blew a certain direction, any fabric on screen would stretch to infinity and obscure 60-70% of the screen. The next issue I had was that for some reason the primary method of control (awkwardly using the number pad) straight up did not work. I tried a different keyboard as well as an old PS2 board and neither allowed any of the diagonal buttons to register.I’m not a computer genius or anything, but I can’t imagine all the technical problems I had running the game being anything more than driver issues and modern operating system changes. If you have an older XP system I bet this game is amazing, from the little bit I suffered through, there was so much awesome content. But if you own a modern gaming computer, just be aware that this game may not play nice with your setup.

ry 20, 2014
												Maybe I don't get this game, or it just wasn't running properly on my computer. A slow and choppy game, Pirates is a baisc open world Pirate game where you sail around trading and plundering.The trade mechanic worked fairly identically to most games with a trade mechanic, and was fine, but the actual pirate battles were fairly lackluster, mostly involving a bit of maneuvering and a whole lot of patience. While you can build up a fleet of ships, this is mostly for maximizing your cargo capacity, and not really for getting increases in combat bonuses (at least as far as I could tell). You can only ever bring one ship into battle, which kept the gameplay very light. If there is depth to be found in this game, I was too frustruated by the incredibly slow pacing to find it.

Split loot disbands your fleet and you lose all your money?  Why would you ever do that?  Retire ends the game?  Why would you ever do that?  No clear benefits to upgrading ships, again because all you do is ram other ships and duel.  No clear point to hiring more men, just more mouths to feed for no reason.  Overall, just a terrible game that you throw away after half an hour.

content:
er 24, 2015
												In this game you take a role of privateer or pirate. You can work for either English, French, Dutch or Spanish - or even for all of them if you time your actions well. There's constantly changing basic economic and political system where player's actions do affect on the bigger picture as well. You can sail, capture ships, fight pirates, trade, do missions, dance with governors daughters and so on. There's many goals to fullfill and many ways to play. Because there's different eras to choose from and the world is open, dynamic and reactive the gaming experience does change lot. There's also different difficulty levels which do have effect. Game's replayability value is quite high and you can get it cheaply, especially on sale. Technically speaking I have been playing this game for something like 30 years from it's early versions on Commodore 64. From those early days they have added more content and huge haul in graphics but the core is same. And it works. Still one of the best, if not best, pirate games there are.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
ber 8, 2015
												Just picture it- Your flagship, a host of galleon's stuffed with spice and sugar, each pirated by a skeleton crew under the watchful eye of your Frigate 'Banshee'. From the aft deck, you stand, uniform tugged by the breeze, gazing back at the spanish main. It's cities burn as people dig through the ashes or else cower under the new governor's you've appointed whom now reign over the new dominions of your country. A great host of men have gathered beneath you, grumbling about being packed like sardines in their triple hammocks but still, eagerly awaiting their share of over one hundred thousand in newly minted Spanish doubloon's. The Spanish, whose military has so spectacularly failed to halt your onslaught now watch in disarray for the dark smudge of smoke on the horizon, a precursor, heralding the terror to come. For the greatest pirate ever to sail, has come to visit and even though the bounty on his head has climbed 'ten thousand, thirty, fifty thousand doubloons?!' still nobody would take them, for none cross....you!I've been playing this game for years now, it's my every now and then game where I'll play one or two careers. Even though it's old, I still get a great kick. It's terribly easy until you're at least a Rougue Captain, but as your character ages, you become slower and all skill fade with age. It's a good, quickish game which will instantly make you happy.If you're not into older games, then this one isn't for you. It is limited in areas, but it's the perfect game for people who enjoy funny, non taxing games that don't require considerable time or background attention or anyone who enjoys Sid Meier as a rule.

content:
2, 2015
												This is a classic game that continues to impress. It's a little difficult to describe, though. You play the role of a young ship captain who is free to roam the caribbean. There are four major powers that control the region. The English, Dutch, Spanish  and the French. You can choose to serve one of them, all of them or none. You patrol the sea looking for targets of opportunity. If you choose to join a nation, you can legally attack their enemies. This is good for when the war ends. It means that nothing was personal and that your former enemies will allow you to pass by without any trouble. You don't have to do that though. You can choose to attack all of them, but then you will have to rely of pirate havens for supplies and repairs. To sum it up: It's a great game that will keep you coming back for more. The only real problem I have with it is the fact that I cannot raise the resolution above 800x600 or the game might crash.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
2, 2015
												Best couple of quid I ever spent, getting this on the Steam Summer Sale.================Pros:+ Despite being utterly dated, the art style of this game is compelling+ There's no shortage of variety, with half a dozen minigames to flesh out the "moving around doing stuff" experience+ Really sells the Caribbean with a lovingly crafted map full of hidden objects and items+ Rewards proactive adventure-buccaneering, while not forcing it down your throat+ The Governors' Daughters ('nuff said)+ PIRATES- Some of the minigames (looking at you land battles) are a wee bit unpolished and somewhat overstay their welcome- The art style of this game is compelling, but it *is* utterly dated- That painful crawl East across the open sea, especially on lower difficulties when the wind never changes direction- A few (infrequent) game breaking bugs - one of which could be a major epilepsy triggerIf you're willing to brave the storms that inherently come with a period-piece of a game, then there's a lot to love about Sid Meier's Pirates. Oh, and that dancing minigame? The trick is to press the buttons in time with the beat. ;)

0, 2015
												Sid Meier's Pirates! (for kiddies) still remember playing this game when I was a kid and when seeing it on a steam sale there was no way to refuse some nostalgia drive. Now that aside, the game mechanics are so dumbed down that even my beagle could play it (gee... that dog has some serious A.D.D), you go from port to port choosing whom you want to serve (or if you want to be a real pirate and target just about anyone).Wind doesn't really affect you much early on (neither does the enemy forces, you can conquer towns with just about a rag-tag bunch of pirates and take over war galleons with your starting ship easily), gaining the heart of a governors daughter (and acquiring useful items) can be as easy as to dance with her a couple of times while you visit a port and talk to its gov and then giving some gifts to her (if it only were that easy... wait... sometimes it is :O )Your crewmates are great, have a lot of personality and background, they will sail with you 'till the end of your days....... nah just kidding they get annoyed if you gather a lot of $ or stuff and don't divide it, dunno about how blackbeard did stuff but I'd be hell lucky being a pirate and quitting after just one year of going around looting and killing and plundering and stealing governor's daughters and.... you get the point.But honestly, all in all, there's some really good fun to be had here, get it on a sale, play it from time to time and you'll get your kicks out of it I know I do.

												Ah Sid Meier how you love to make people waste their entire day away on just one video game. He does it well that's for sure, and Pirates (Next to civilization) Shows this better than anything. With this 2004 release being the best.Pros:-Very Piratey...Yohohoho.-Capturing, Plundering, and Digging up treasure never gets old.-The game let's you increase the difficulty the farther you get in the game-Restoring your family feels good-There's a good amount of upgrades-Pillaging Towns is the best part in my view. It acts as a Turn Bases Strategy, with some nice mechanics-You can Fight actual pirates like Black Beard.Cons:-If you can't control yourself while playing video games. Then STAY FAR AWAY! This game will take your entire life in a blink of an eye.-It's very tedious. If you can't stand grinding you will hate this game.-Dancing STINKS! If you don't have a good num pad then good luck trying to play that minigame.Overall if you like being a pirate then pick this up. Oh but remember something. The Spainish are the best to raid. (SO MUCH MONEY!)

content:
r 30, 2015
												This game is great. In fact, it's probably one of the most fun games I've ever played. You get to live the fantasy of being a pirate...not with all the realities of wasting months of your life on the sea and all the infections that come with that, but you get to fire cannons and have sword fights on deck and raid colonial fortresses and dance with the governors' beautiful daughters. There is plenty of variety in what you can do in this game. If you're tired of capturing ships for profit, go take an outpost for your favorite nation; search for buried treasure; play the main story line; hunt down famous pirates; get captured just so you can have fun sneaking out of jail. This game never gets boring, and the difficulty levels are sufficient to either give you a leisurely stroll through the Caribbean or a truly gripping fight at sea. Highly recommend it.

er 24, 2016
												I know what you are thinking already.  This?  Seriously?!?No BS, this game will suck hours out of your life like the government sucks money out of your wallet.  It is insane how much fun it is to try and get a broadside in on a Spanish trade vessel, or maneuver armies in attempts to take out cities.  Not to mention the sandbox environment, probably the first.  There are so many options to choose how to play the game, you will probably take a long time to play the same game twice, unless you do it intentionally.  Probably the best part though, is how easy it is to pick up and put down.  Only have ten minutes?  No problem, raid a couple spanish ships, hit save and quit and boom, your done.  ::Aside; what ever happened to such a simple function?::No matter the computer, whether laptop or gaming rig, Sid Meier's Pirates will have a place on the hard drive, right by Solitaire.

ber 3, 2015
												After putting in my 40+ hours at the desk job, it's nice to come home to a rewarding game that doesn't require too much brain power.  At around ten dollars, this kept me entertained, relaxed, and engaged for most of a weekend.  It is well worth the cost.  Many developers now are pushing for a more real-life experience with darker visuals and more deeply challenging  game play, but I don't want to play those types of games all the time.  There's still plenty of room left on the SSD for brighter, happier visuals and simpler, joyful games.  I did run into a bug once where my ship got stuck, but the fix is to reload the last autosave battle, and you're unstuck... no big deal.

												I was playing Pirates! for a year after it came out on PSP. I borrowed it as often as I could from the library and played so much I recognized where every treasure could spawn at from one scrap of the map. I would dedicate entire days to me lying on the couch, trying to sack a new town for the Dutch. I became so skilled that I wouldn't be slowed on the hardest difficulty.However, even with all of that work, I never 100% completed the game. It's so easy to get caught up in the politics, treasure hunting, intregue, and dancing. This game can keep you so busy that you'll be retired before you know it.The only way for this game to be made better is to release an HD remake (or sequal) with some minor adjustments:Improved graphics (better textures, water effects, etc)Improved framerate (60+ would be ideal)Custom keybinding and controller supportModding support Other than that, it's a really good game. 9/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
, 2015
												A classic pirate game from 2004. It's incredibly fun (Even in today's standards) by the fact that ship, crew and money management all come into play in this non-linear quest of; anything.The quest systems usually come along the lines of;Kill this pirate (after awhile, you'll receive PART OF a map obtained for the next quest)Find this family memberFind this pirates treasure (GOLD! Very valuable.)and so on. Although, you can selectively stray away from these quests, even though they award you with certain benefits and instead go and help a certain faction (English, Dutch, Spanish, French.) to obtain promotions and thus, privileges that benefit you and your ship.The game includes three variants of fighting;  -First: Ship vs Ship combat. In this, your ship will be plotted against a ship that you happened to run into on your voyage. It's basically firing cannons to each other, but you can gain strategic advantages by unlocking different cannon types and upgrades. (Normal = Hull, Chain = Sails, Grape = Crew)  -Second: Captain vs Captain. Usually if you besiege a fort under certain circumstances or you run into the enemy ship in naval combat (See variant of fighting 'First') in which you'll be pitted against the captain of the enemy. It's really just press buttons at certain times to win. Simple right? But just as before, upgrades and other things will cause you to win/lose like the amount of crew you have compared to them, and your advantage bar.   -Third: Siege. If you decide to besiege a fort, then you will gain a time based strategy feel, in which you will gain a few troops of different qualities, as well as the enemy gaining their own. You must fight using your troops and play with their qualities in order to achieve victory. The graphics style is rather well fleshed out for it's time, and is incredibly smooth in all areas. The art style seems to fit really will with the Pirate game.Dialogue isn't exactly the thing you'll be reading constantly, however, sometimes useful information will pop up, like trade ships located or the location of treasure. So occasionally you may want to listen!The options menu is decked out with everything you'll need. Including resolution, toggling of certain lighting and trilinear filtering. However, you shouldn't have to change anything now-a-days due to the high-end processors in our computers.Great story! Although the dialogue as noted above it rather low-end, the story is actually incredibly good!Cons:-Although the quest line, it has rather repetitive game play. Depending on luck and skill, the game can fly by and you'll already have some of the top end ships.-Enemies do exactly the same thing (Linear AI programming)Absolutely wonderful game. I have no huge disappointments about it. NoCeBo - 9/10.

0, 2015
												Sid Meier's Pirates! (for kiddies) still remember playing this game when I was a kid and when seeing it on a steam sale there was no way to refuse some nostalgia drive. Now that aside, the game mechanics are so dumbed down that even my beagle could play it (gee... that dog has some serious A.D.D), you go from port to port choosing whom you want to serve (or if you want to be a real pirate and target just about anyone).Wind doesn't really affect you much early on (neither does the enemy forces, you can conquer towns with just about a rag-tag bunch of pirates and take over war galleons with your starting ship easily), gaining the heart of a governors daughter (and acquiring useful items) can be as easy as to dance with her a couple of times while you visit a port and talk to its gov and then giving some gifts to her (if it only were that easy... wait... sometimes it is :O )Your crewmates are great, have a lot of personality and background, they will sail with you 'till the end of your days....... nah just kidding they get annoyed if you gather a lot of $ or stuff and don't divide it, dunno about how blackbeard did stuff but I'd be hell lucky being a pirate and quitting after just one year of going around looting and killing and plundering and stealing governor's daughters and.... you get the point.But honestly, all in all, there's some really good fun to be had here, get it on a sale, play it from time to time and you'll get your kicks out of it I know I do.

content:
y 21, 2016
												This game...it's hard to describe it exactly in an overarching view.Let me go ahead and talk about the factions in this game.Spain: Huge amounts of land and ships, but the ships suck and the land cities are heavily guarded. Ships are usually huge, but slow, and have a huge amount of crew, but the ships seem like they are made out of cardboard. Has most cities in the game. Also, the Spanish are at war with everyone almost all the time.England: Sloops and Brigs as far as the eye can see! England has some of the fastest ships, and remember how I said the Spanish ships are made of cardboard? Well, the English cannons fire the equivalent of napalm in a ball when hitting a Spanish ship. Besides the Spanish, they have the most amount of cities, although most are islands and not on the mainland Americas.France: The French have some what I'd consider all around style of ships. They are a mix of ships and power, but they work. They have less than the English, but aren't doing the worst.Netherlands/Dutch: "Oh sweet almighty Jesus, we are screwed," is probably what you'd think if you were the Dutch king. Basically, the Dutch aren't exactly doing the best when it comes to amount of land or types of ships, but it's much easier to buy and sell in Dutch markets, as well as get promotions. Basically, you want more recruits and buy food cheaper? You want to be Dutch.Jesuit Missions: Basically, think of a bunch of priests living on islands. There you go. They have no real alignment or ships, they just are there and sell food. Talk to them to help with your main quest to find your family.Pirate settlements: Like a regular city, but you can usually only get recruits and food here, but you can end up helping the pirate leader to take over cities.You do NOT have to side with anyone. Basically, the game allows you to have the freedom of you choosing the options to help anyone. I, personally, help the Dutch all the time (because it's actually easy if you are good with economic type of gameplay), but you could, for example, help the Dutch one time, help the English one time, help the Spanish once, then help the French, and have everyone love you.This game is amazing, and it has multiple minigames of fencing, land battles, ship battles, and, yes, dancing.

content:
r 17, 2015
												A fun pirate game set in the Caribbean, during the 17th Century. You are a privateer looking to make his fortune and rescues if lost family. It is an early open world game, in that although there is a notional storyline, in practice you tend to end up sailing the seas, capturing or sinking ships with impunity whilst leaving your family to rot in captivity. The gameplay is not only confined to sailing the ocean blue, there is a host other (nefarious) activities to take part in, ranging from sacking cities and copious amounts of swordplay to wooing the daughters of cites governors with your masterful dancing skills. The controls are simple to pick up, although can hard to master are higher difficulty levels – a case in point is the dancing. At low difficulty you are given clear guides to which button to press. This becomes subtle hand gestures at higher levels, easy to miss as you stumble around the dancefloor like you have had too much grog. Graphically it is pretty to look at, without be Assassins Creed Black Flag. Bear in mind this was first released in 1987. It has been updated for modern OS but is still more functional than flashyGameplay	8Graphics	        6Control		7Fun		        8Overall		7.5

												Sidmeier's Pirates is a remake of an older version of the Game and ticks all the boxes right for doing so. Having said that. I have 10.5 hours in it and finished it - that said higher difficulties from the start are still open to me, as you are obligated to start at the easiest difficulty when you first start the game but you can during the game up the difficulty by 'dividing the loot'.It has several 'mini-games' including dancing/romancing governor daughters, attacking cities, and fighting on ships. These mini-games are not overly hard, but not too difficult that is just a breeze. As you can interspace them the way you want the mini-games are never bothersome, in my opinion.The atmosphere and humor of the game is its major selling point and as such it a good little game for a bit of relaxing. And with the difficulties, different starting eras, and starting proficiencies you can definately make it harder on yourself to get a more challenging experience should you wish it, but to me it does not seem as if it was created to make you have deep low and mountain peak highs, but rather a relaxing giggle.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
12, 2015
												This is an old game, but I gotta say, it's a good one.I got the urge to play some kinda pirate simulation game a while back, and there has just been nothing out on the market like that of late, unless you're into Assassin's Creed.. which I'm not. (because Ubisoft.)  But I found this on sale for a few bucks.. and thought.. Ok.. Pirates.. Sid Meier.. sure, why not.  It was a good choice.Lots of things you can do..different goals you can try for.  The mechanics are somewhat simplistic.. I mean, it's a 2004 remake of a 1987 game, so you can't expect too much sophistication out of it..  But that said, if you're looking for something to swash your buckle.. (or would that be buckle your swash?), this'll do it.  The minigame mechanics for fencing and dancing are easy at the lowest difficulty, but get quite challenging at higher ones unless you've got good "twitch gamer" reflexes... So most of us will find a decent challenge available.The AI does some strange things at times.. that's pretty much to be expected..   Like in my latest playthrough, I decided to be a English pure "privateer".. following the terms of my "Letter of Marque and Reprisal"..  Drove the French and the Dutch completely out of the Caribbean, and the Spanish are down to just a half a dozen cities on the coast of Mexico and Central America..  The last French and Dutch cities to fall, and the last Spanish city on the northern islands, all responded by sending invasion force after invasion force, sometimes 3 or 4 frigates at once laden with troops.. over and over.. out of cities with barely any money or troops due to my blockade..  which, of course, would be impossible with any sense of "realism"..But that doesn't detract from the fun. In fact, it makes it even more amusing.. "How can I get the AI to freak out this time?" becomes it's own sort of meta-game.  At least for me. I personally would *love* to see a *sequel* to this game.. not a HD remake, or a relaunch.. but a full Pirates! 2.  Updated engine, graphics.. merging geopolitics into it a bit borrowing elements from the Civilization series.. Really treating the naval situation and piracy in the region during that time as it was historically... a proxy war between the competing empires of Europe..  Character development maybe, a skill tree, so you get better at your skills along with upgrading gear, instead of just getting bonuses from equipment..  More promotion options, etc..  The ability to have actual fleet combat, and the ability to found your own colonies...But probably the only actual real *downside* to this game.. is that I haven't figured out how to actually be the aggressor against a foreign city... the only way I've found so far is to just look and sink a whole bunch of their ships till the harbor guns get ♥♥♥♥♥♥ enough to take a pot shot at you.. then you get the option to "attack"..  I wanna bombard em from sea, then unleash the pirate hordes.. lol..But even with that annoyance, and the limitations of this being a very old remake of an even older game.. it's a classic.. Revolutionary for it's time, and has aged quite well. Give it a try.

er 6, 2015
												I have always loved this game, it's a pretty simple game that isn't very challenging, but I love it.Pros:•Wont matter for a lot of people, butvery little mouse input needed, great for playing on the bus, or somewhere where I don't have an external mouse with my laptop•Graphics still hold decently well, the animations are a bit laughable, but the graphics don't hurt my eyes.•Very little story.  While the game does have a story, it doesn't push you into doing it at all, so your free to do whatever you want. Considdered a pro, because a lot of simular games like this force you to do the main storyline, and limit the open-world.Cons:•Some of the minigames can get a bit reppetitive. Dancing is very important in the game, but is not very fun, and I hate sneaking into towns. The most common ones like sword-fighting or ship battles stay fun.•Not very difficult. Even on swashbucking difficulty (the hardest one) the only thing I have trouble with is a few sword fights, but if you use the cutlass and taunt often, they aren't a problem.Overall, this game deffinetly is not for everyone. I have always loved this style of game, so it's easy for me to love this game. The game isn't very expensive, especially on sale, so I would whole-heartedly recomend picking it up if it looks even slightly appealing to you.

number of helpful: No ratings yet2 people found this review funny
content:
10
												This game--- oh Lordy have mercy, this game! Going into 'Sid Meier's Prirates!', I had the impression it was going to be an overall decent experience, but without much direction. The game has a story, but, in my first few minutes, I had feared it'd be too open-ended and not give me much to go on. Wrong.You're set out proper into the ocean with a decent crew, a small ship and a good six or so months worth of food, and are tasked with finding your captured family. While this may seem daunting, seeing as there are sixteen greek family members to all track down, it's surprisingly simple to start the story. Simply make your mark by capturing a few easy ships, do some quests for some governers and such-- before you know it, you're hunting down pirates, treasure, merchant vessles and everything of the sort, easy peasy!The game is wonderfully simple to get into, and it kept me hooked for hours. Couldn't stopl playing unit I demended to myself "Go eat something and finish your homework--- THEN you'll have EVEN MORE time to play!" And so I'm writing this review eating one heck of a tuna sandwich, if I do say so myself. It's got parsley and mayo in-- I put lettice and some mango on it, and a little bit of hidden valley ranch---The game.It's awesome.If you're looking for a light-hearted but still involved pirate game where you carve out a ledgend other pirates will envy, this is the game for you! Fluid mechanics, everyhting feels wonderful to do-- just... I waited for a sale-- and this was undoubtedly some of the best three bucks of my life. Usually 10 but heck-- I'd say it's totally worth it, there's just so much to be had!

content:
y 28, 2016
												Stupidly fun pirates game. There's a main quest to follow, but you can ignore it if you'd like. There are lost cities to discover, treasure to be unburied, towns to be sacked! Work your way up to the number 1 pirate by defeating famous pirates (including Blackbeard!). It's a game of revenge and adventuring, but even a taste of romance as you dance your way through all the governor's daughters. Literally dancing, because there's a dancing minigame.One thing I particularly enjoyed about this game was the combination of real-time and turn-based strategy. Most of it's real-time, but oftentimes if you sack a town, you'll have to pit your pirates against their soldiers in a fun turn-based game (the only time that isn't the case is if your number of pirate greatly trumps their number of soldiers; then you'll just have a sword fight with the Captain of the Guards). It's a fun game with several levels of difficulty, plus you can start at different time periods, which will also help decrease or increase the difficulty of the game, so replayability is high.

r 22, 2016
												***Should have done a sequel for this game instead of reworking Civilization 5***Anyways, I bought this game for nostalgic reasoning, played it near initial release.If you've never played it before, it will give you that initial burst of enjoyment you've been looking for, right away, you'll experience a ship battle which has strategy with a punch of arcade style battle.The game is full of mini-games but obviously the majority of us are here for the ship battle and ship upgrades!A ran into a bug that spawned my fleet on shore and it was stuck there, overwriting both autosaves so I could no longer continue.Sid Meier's Pirates! becomes repetitive quickly in a sense you know it didn't really have to.  What I mean is, all the mechanics of the game are awesome ideas, but are lacking volume.  For instance, the amount of ships in the game is very light.  You will easily get the best ship and be disappointed quickly by this.  I mean, this is fine, but the amount of content they could easily add to a sequel makes my head spin and can't figure out why they have not.There are no good pirate games out there, IMO, that offer the arcade play style that Sid Meier's Pirates does.  The game is simple and satisfying.---If they ever made a sequel, this would be my fantasy features*way more ships*diplomatic relations more diverse*being able to create your own faction/nation*rampart(nes) city attacking and defending mechanics with modern twist*multiplayer- lot's more but I have to run

												This is a minigame fiesta that even Miyamoto would be proud of.  I could win this game on hardest difficulty with a beer in one hand while doing my taxes on a seperate screen.   You would think that would make it boring- you'd be dead wrong. This game is the epitome of the Sid Meier Sorcery™.   It's a perfect mix of theme and mechanic, people of all ages and backgrounds could enjoy it- it's just a perfect game, really. He could merely update the graphics, add a couple more minigames, and sell it for 60 bucks and I would seriously consider it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
26
												Sid Meier's Pirates is an interesting mix of genres presented in a sort of "proto-sandbox" fashion: players take on the role of a swashbuckler living during the 17th century "Golden Age of Piracy". You may pursue the in-game story of searching the Caribbean Sea for their lost family members, but the game does not push this object on you but every so often, meaning that players are fully free to disregard the main storyline in order to make their own distinct niche out of Caribbean life. These activities include ship navigation and exploration, land combat (presented as a turn-based strategy minigame, ala Civilization), and courting noblewomen (presented as a rhythm minigame).The graphics are colorful and have the right amount of cartoonishness to them, and the often upbeat soundtrack helps put a smile on my face every time I boot this game up. If any of this sounds interesting, I'd say to jump head-on into Sid Meier's Pirates, as I don't think a simple review conveys how much fun this game is, so much as sitting down and making of it what you will does. The seas are what you make of them!Also, for those of you who originally owned this game on CD like I did, Steam will be able to read and use your old save files!

												I played this a lot years ago, and it's still very enjoyable.  It's a pirate simulator with gameplay broken into a series of mini-games.  Sailing, sword-fighting, dancing, and sneaking are each individual mini-games, most of them similar to quick time events, and there is a simple system for dealing with food, morale, crew, loot, and all that.  There's also a story but it's not very interesting.  It's weakness is a lack of depth.  You will get tired of it eventually, because it becomes quite repetetive after a while.

												Although the game squarely qualifies as old now, I couldn't resist buying it given how much I played it years ago, and how powerful the memories of it.The story offers a simple and straightforward red thread to follow for completion, but leaves so much room for exploration, choices and personal characterization (or lack thereof) that it actually allows many replays without getting boring.The minigames are of course a bit repetitive, but that's not something that ever bothers me, especially since they're based on rhythm and reactivity. Only the slow sailing across the map got annoying after a while, and that's a feature; you're NOT supposed to cross over the whole ocean without pause or action.Basically, this game is a blast for any player who likes writing their own story.One day, I'll publish the epic chronicles of the dreaded legendary pirate who attacked and took over the whole Spanish Armada with his lone but glorious war canoe Croustibat! :D

content:
2, 2015
												This is a classic game that continues to impress. It's a little difficult to describe, though. You play the role of a young ship captain who is free to roam the caribbean. There are four major powers that control the region. The English, Dutch, Spanish  and the French. You can choose to serve one of them, all of them or none. You patrol the sea looking for targets of opportunity. If you choose to join a nation, you can legally attack their enemies. This is good for when the war ends. It means that nothing was personal and that your former enemies will allow you to pass by without any trouble. You don't have to do that though. You can choose to attack all of them, but then you will have to rely of pirate havens for supplies and repairs. To sum it up: It's a great game that will keep you coming back for more. The only real problem I have with it is the fact that I cannot raise the resolution above 800x600 or the game might crash.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
2, 2015
												Best couple of quid I ever spent, getting this on the Steam Summer Sale.================Pros:+ Despite being utterly dated, the art style of this game is compelling+ There's no shortage of variety, with half a dozen minigames to flesh out the "moving around doing stuff" experience+ Really sells the Caribbean with a lovingly crafted map full of hidden objects and items+ Rewards proactive adventure-buccaneering, while not forcing it down your throat+ The Governors' Daughters ('nuff said)+ PIRATES- Some of the minigames (looking at you land battles) are a wee bit unpolished and somewhat overstay their welcome- The art style of this game is compelling, but it *is* utterly dated- That painful crawl East across the open sea, especially on lower difficulties when the wind never changes direction- A few (infrequent) game breaking bugs - one of which could be a major epilepsy triggerIf you're willing to brave the storms that inherently come with a period-piece of a game, then there's a lot to love about Sid Meier's Pirates. Oh, and that dancing minigame? The trick is to press the buttons in time with the beat. ;)

												I was playing Pirates! for a year after it came out on PSP. I became so skilled that I wouldn't be slowed on the hardest difficulty.However, even with all of that work, I never 100% completed the game. It's so easy to get caught up in the politics, treasure hunting, intregue, and dancing. This game can keep you so busy that you'll be retired before you know it.The only way for this game to be made better is to release an HD remake (or sequal) with some minor adjustments:Improved graphics (better textures, water effects, etc)Improved framerate (60+ would be ideal)Custom keybinding and controller supportModding support Other than that, it's a really good game. 9/10

A balanced and engrossing mix of elements including tactics, trading, sailing, rpg(revenge), humor, Disney (yes), combat, and rommance！！The details of every fraction is extremely well handeled. I like how they put 3 levels of rommance options for each nation and you can potentially pick your GF from 24 different girls! That's more than Skyrim! Though usually I would skip the "plain" ones. That didn't take too long since it's pretty self-explanatory. 9.5 out of 10 the 0.5 taken out because I had a headach finding lost relatives/city the map for those missions seems to be auto-generated at random. Sometimes it tells you to search "The south of XX city" you could end up spending 3 hours hiking through the area in vain. Not sure if it's a bug or I wasn't doing the right thing.

content:
y 21, 2016
												This game...it's hard to describe it exactly in an overarching view.Let me go ahead and talk about the factions in this game.Spain: Huge amounts of land and ships, but the ships suck and the land cities are heavily guarded. Ships are usually huge, but slow, and have a huge amount of crew, but the ships seem like they are made out of cardboard. Has most cities in the game. Also, the Spanish are at war with everyone almost all the time.England: Sloops and Brigs as far as the eye can see! England has some of the fastest ships, and remember how I said the Spanish ships are made of cardboard? Well, the English cannons fire the equivalent of napalm in a ball when hitting a Spanish ship. Besides the Spanish, they have the most amount of cities, although most are islands and not on the mainland Americas.France: The French have some what I'd consider all around style of ships. They are a mix of ships and power, but they work. They have less than the English, but aren't doing the worst.Netherlands/Dutch: "Oh sweet almighty Jesus, we are screwed," is probably what you'd think if you were the Dutch king. Basically, the Dutch aren't exactly doing the best when it comes to amount of land or types of ships, but it's much easier to buy and sell in Dutch markets, as well as get promotions. Basically, you want more recruits and buy food cheaper? You want to be Dutch.Jesuit Missions: Basically, think of a bunch of priests living on islands. There you go. They have no real alignment or ships, they just are there and sell food. Talk to them to help with your main quest to find your family.Pirate settlements: Like a regular city, but you can usually only get recruits and food here, but you can end up helping the pirate leader to take over cities.You do NOT have to side with anyone. Basically, the game allows you to have the freedom of you choosing the options to help anyone. I, personally, help the Dutch all the time (because it's actually easy if you are good with economic type of gameplay), but you could, for example, help the Dutch one time, help the English one time, help the Spanish once, then help the French, and have everyone love you.This game is amazing, and it has multiple minigames of fencing, land battles, ship battles, and, yes, dancing.

0, 2015
												Sid Meier's Pirates! (for kiddies) still remember playing this game when I was a kid and when seeing it on a steam sale there was no way to refuse some nostalgia drive. Now that aside, the game mechanics are so dumbed down that even my beagle could play it (gee... that dog has some serious A.D.D), you go from port to port choosing whom you want to serve (or if you want to be a real pirate and target just about anyone).Wind doesn't really affect you much early on (neither does the enemy forces, you can conquer towns with just about a rag-tag bunch of pirates and take over war galleons with your starting ship easily), gaining the heart of a governors daughter (and acquiring useful items) can be as easy as to dance with her a couple of times while you visit a port and talk to its gov and then giving some gifts to her (if it only were that easy... wait... sometimes it is :O )Your crewmates are great, have a lot of personality and background, they will sail with you 'till the end of your days....... nah just kidding they get annoyed if you gather a lot of $ or stuff and don't divide it, dunno about how blackbeard did stuff but I'd be hell lucky being a pirate and quitting after just one year of going around looting and killing and plundering and stealing governor's daughters and.... you get the point.But honestly, all in all, there's some really good fun to be had here, get it on a sale, play it from time to time and you'll get your kicks out of it I know I do.

												This is the first PC game I ever played so it has a certain special place in my heart. Even in 2006 with less than 1 GB thius game did more than Far Cry did in 20+ GB. We have an open world, a crazy amount of vessels to sail, an active and important political system, swordfights, upgrades, treasure hunts, and so much more. content:
er 27, 2016
												Graphics: 5/10Sound: 4/10Mechanic: 5/10Story: 4/10Action: 8/10Originality: 6/10Lasting Fun: 4/10and all considering that this is a game from a totally different age of computer games.Quite a good and funny game but definitely not what you expect from a modern game any longer. The game was released in 1987 and kinda overhauled and re-released sometimes around 2004. Considering the age of even the later version graphics and game look pretty good. I bought it for about 4 bucks which is an ok price, but I would never have paid 10+ for it. This game is not a simulation, it's more an arcarde style action game where you sail around, sink ships of several factions or pirates, do some politics and a little trading and can go for treasure hunting as well. actually the game has all a good pirate game needs. Yet, the action becomes stale pretty fast. Trading is kind of tedious as it requires you to have large ships and go long distances. Sailing long distances is punished in the game as your crew is going to desert you faster than you can replace them. In the later game this seems to get much better, but getting there is not funny at all. You can use your small starting loop to easily take a full blown war galley as prize. But you will not have the men to maintain it for long, even if you have loads of gold. The game is pretty open to your actions, there is no fix chain of quests you have to follow, although there are very helpful quests. The information in the game and the presentation of your ships is bad. You do get zero info about the capacities of your ships (you can carry 60 guns in small ships, but you don't see easily how many guns get fired and how many are just cargo). There is no full size view of your ship in the menues (I wish I could have seen it in full size and rotating), no fluff info (ship type, tonnage, sails, guns, etc). Hunting pirates was a laugh, I brought down No. 1 from the list within my very first 15 minutes if gameplay. Orientation is hard sometimes when leaving harbour, the compass is pretty simple and yous camera view very narrow. Although many seem to have enjoyed the cartoonist fun style of the game I missed the feeling of grim and dangerous piracy. It feels a bit like playing pirate in your bath tub. Good for a moment but nothing that makes me remember it or want to proceed further. Nice but yesterday.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
, 2015
												A classic pirate game from 2004. It's incredibly fun (Even in today's standards) by the fact that ship, crew and money management all come into play in this non-linear quest of; anything.The quest systems usually come along the lines of;Kill this pirate (after awhile, you'll receive PART OF a map obtained for the next quest)Find this family memberFind this pirates treasure (GOLD! Very valuable.)and so on. Although, you can selectively stray away from these quests, even though they award you with certain benefits and instead go and help a certain faction (English, Dutch, Spanish, French.) to obtain promotions and thus, privileges that benefit you and your ship.The game includes three variants of fighting;  -First: Ship vs Ship combat. In this, your ship will be plotted against a ship that you happened to run into on your voyage. It's basically firing cannons to each other, but you can gain strategic advantages by unlocking different cannon types and upgrades. (Normal = Hull, Chain = Sails, Grape = Crew)  -Second: Captain vs Captain. Usually if you besiege a fort under certain circumstances or you run into the enemy ship in naval combat (See variant of fighting 'First') in which you'll be pitted against the captain of the enemy. It's really just press buttons at certain times to win. Simple right? But just as before, upgrades and other things will cause you to win/lose like the amount of crew you have compared to them, and your advantage bar.   -Third: Siege. If you decide to besiege a fort, then you will gain a time based strategy feel, in which you will gain a few troops of different qualities, as well as the enemy gaining their own. You must fight using your troops and play with their qualities in order to achieve victory. The graphics style is rather well fleshed out for it's time, and is incredibly smooth in all areas. The art style seems to fit really will with the Pirate game.Dialogue isn't exactly the thing you'll be reading constantly, however, sometimes useful information will pop up, like trade ships located or the location of treasure. So occasionally you may want to listen!The options menu is decked out with everything you'll need. Including resolution, toggling of certain lighting and trilinear filtering. However, you shouldn't have to change anything now-a-days due to the high-end processors in our computers.Great story! Although the dialogue as noted above it rather low-end, the story is actually incredibly good!Cons:-Although the quest line, it has rather repetitive game play. Depending on luck and skill, the game can fly by and you'll already have some of the top end ships.-Enemies do exactly the same thing (Linear AI programming)Absolutely wonderful game. I have no huge disappointments about it. NoCeBo - 9/10.

0, 2015
												Sid Meier's Pirates! (for kiddies) still remember playing this game when I was a kid and when seeing it on a steam sale there was no way to refuse some nostalgia drive. Now that aside, the game mechanics are so dumbed down that even my beagle could play it (gee... that dog has some serious A.D.D), you go from port to port choosing whom you want to serve (or if you want to be a real pirate and target just about anyone).Wind doesn't really affect you much early on (neither does the enemy forces, you can conquer towns with just about a rag-tag bunch of pirates and take over war galleons with your starting ship easily), gaining the heart of a governors daughter (and acquiring useful items) can be as easy as to dance with her a couple of times while you visit a port and talk to its gov and then giving some gifts to her (if it only were that easy... wait... sometimes it is :O )Your crewmates are great, have a lot of personality and background, they will sail with you 'till the end of your days....... nah just kidding they get annoyed if you gather a lot of $ or stuff and don't divide it, dunno about how blackbeard did stuff but I'd be hell lucky being a pirate and quitting after just one year of going around looting and killing and plundering and stealing governor's daughters and.... you get the point.But honestly, all in all, there's some really good fun to be had here, get it on a sale, play it from time to time and you'll get your kicks out of it I know I do.

Reynaldo was a French Privateer raiding English and Spanish shipping he came to amass a small fortune in prizes and plunder he soon became famous and took on more crew, but soon things changed for the worse the French made peace with the spanish and the English merchants were all too scared to sail home. with the money stoping he soon took to darker pursuits, buying strange medicine from a myterious man in a backroom of a shady for 6000 Gold the men soon became worried for their captain, but more so for the loot. the spending was rampent, 3000 gold here a few thousand more there. soon the fortune he had spent years building was well deminished he resorted to outright Piracy to keep the crew in line. he started spinning tales to governors daughters dancing with them hoping to lead them on for more money to buy "exotic" and "mystical" items, but the crew finally agreed it was time for Mutiniy but just as it happened they suddenly came under fire, an English Pirate Hunter masking itself as french. the Crew returned fire a round of chain shot destroyed the main sail and the English promptly surrendered, a large amount of gold was plundered, and the Crew Mutinied taking the Gold and the Captains ship leaving him stranded on an Island.  Thus the final score is 10/10 would buy strange medicine from a mysterious man in a dark backroom of a Shady tavarn.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
er 18, 2016
												This is a very good strategical and casual game, and a king amoung pirate games. It's story-driven, and there isn't a whole lot of choice-making, and there isn't much of an item system (ie no inventory) but there are still collectibles, armor, swords, guns, all the likes to buy from the mysterious merchants in the corner of taverns. Being able to take and pick from multiple different types and grades of ships is a good part of the game, along with making your own sails and choosing which flag you'll sail under. The naval combat, in all honesty, is slow and boring, so if I were you, just board them already! Don't sit there and fire cannons, they barely do anything. Boarding is less extravagant than most other pirate games. Basically you pick your sword (Go Rapiers!), which can be upgraded with new sets of swords you can buy, and defeat your opposing captain in a Hollywood-style match of sword fighting before your crew gets murdered. Should you win, you will be deserted or captured somewhere, and be left with little to nothing -- this is when the saving slots and loading come in handy, cause who the heck actually serves prison time in RPGs? If you beat the captain, which won't take much time to master doing, he will be everso conveniently knocked off his ship, once again, in a Hollywood cinematic style. This is especially true when facing a famous pirate such as the cliche Blackbeard. There are plenty other times in the game where you'll need your valiant swordsmanship, so be prepared for that. Other than that, it's working up the ranks of kingdom militaries, winning the heart of a governor's daughter (or a few, if you're into that...), finding your lost family members (NOT a spoiler, btw), and pillaging and exploring as you see fit. Don't forget to do some special missions along the way, trust me, they're actually fun and not a waste of time. Just try not to get too frustrated when searching the endless jungle lands for treasures and buildings, because you'll start to make so much more sense of the treasure maps you pick up as you go. There's more that I could say here, but you're probably already itching your mouse to hit that Add To Wishlist button, so I'll letcha go.TL;DR: Pirates!

												Sid Meier's Pirates! is a game with true staying power. Dated by todays standards, any fans of the fictionalized 'Golden Age of Piracy', that can get past the aging graphics and interface, will be deeply rewarded.  From ship combat to searching for treasure on land, Pirates! touches on them all. Trading, pillaging, romancing and prestige; all await the intrepid adventurer!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
er 24, 2016
												I discovered this pearl of a game on a LAN way back. One of the other attendees was just sitting there playing Pirates while the rest of us where shooting each other dead in Counter-Stike and gibbing it up in Unreal Tournament.It struck me as odd he'd be wasting valuable "LAN-time" (we only managed to get together like once or twice a year) playing a single-player game, so I felt intriqued to have a look.At a first glance it looked stupid: Just sailing around with his ship and picking random fights. But I gave it a shot and I was hooked for months to come.There's was certain blizz to sail about the caribbean. The game was beautiful in it's own way: One didn't pay attention to the blatant disregard for scale or the rather poor textures, because the world felt so alive with tropical colours. The gameplay was fun and varied, once you got in to the "nitty-gritty" of the core gameplay as well as all the mini-games. There was also a suprising depth to the game, where the market changed and countries would got to war and make peace. Simply put the game felt alive, and you where free to to what you wanted within this world.I could probably go on trying to describe the magic that makes Sid Meier's Pirates so enticing, but based on my own experience I think it's just one of those games that has to be experienced.If one could vote for the next big remaster, Sid Meier's Pirates would be on the top of my list.

ry 3, 2016
												The game in its core is a collection of mini-games that all work towards a common goal and make it more than the sum of its parts. Lots of activities in the game, from sea battles, trading, "massive" town sieges, finding buried treasure and all the other pirate stuff you expect to do in a game with the name "Pirates!".There is something here for everyone I would say and you should really have it in your library. It is easy to jump in and out of and won't take a lots of time to enjoy it. The only thing I don't like about this game is that the movement and action keys are bound to the numpad, but with that said it does not take away from the game that much and you get used to it pretty quick. Overall, it is one of the best pirate themed games ever and it is dirt cheap, especially if on sale.

content:
ber 19, 2013
												The definitive pirate video game. Capture and plunder ships and towns, search for lost relatives, engage in battle on the high seas, pick your weapon and duel another captain, and more. While some of what you do can get to become tedious or repetitive, and not everything is perfect, this game still has a massive fun factor.You start the game and get to play for any of the 4 different factions: the Dutch, Fench, Spanish and English. Over the course of the game, you'll complete various tasks for each faction, as well as personal objectives, finally retiring in your old age and in failing health.This game is worth the price even when not on sale, but it's a total steal when it's discounted. Pure fun, plain and simple.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
ry 14
												I absolutely love this game, but take it with a grain of salt because I love every pirate game ever made. The main story was fairly engaging, the trading system is surprisingly fun, and the scripted fights are usually fun and visually cool (you can throw a guy out a window!). That said, on the higher difficulties ship battles, dances, and fights can become a huge trial to get through. A ton of aspects in the game rely on a sort of quicktime click x to do the right thing mechanic that is sometimes cool because it’s so simple but can get rather boring and frustrating after a while. If you’re interested in playing a pirate and exploring the world, then give this one a try. 8/10 best pirate game I’ve seen in a long time.
